Review:
I've owned this car seat for two years now, so I'll point out the things I like about it.
I own a Toyota Camry. This seat is installed on the side front facing. My son just turned 6 and is still in the 5-point harness (note- harness can be used until your child is 65 lbs and 50 inches tall). I've had no problems getting this seat super tight using LATCH.
Last year my son threw up in this seat and it had to be taken apart and cleaned. It was irritating just like any other seat, but I put the whole cover in the machine and there wasn't any damage done to it. (The fabric and straps on this seat don't have any visible deformities despite it being over two years old.) When I did take it apart, it was nice to see how well padded it is.
One good thing, but also bad thing, about this seat is how wide it is. If you're not planning to put a third person in your backseat, it's not a big deal. However, my other son's car seat is a Recaro Proride (also notoriously wide) so any third passenger back there has to be either an older child or a very uncomfortable adult. The good thing about it being so wide is that it's comfortable for my son. On long trips he likes to cross his legs and will fall asleep that way.
The only other "complaint" I have about this seat is the cupholders. They are not plastic all the way around, but held by a strip of elastic, so something like a toy car is going to slide right out. Top heavy drinks have fallen out during turns. They are irritating, but all the good things outweigh this one small issue.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: 65 lbs and 50 inches tall
Installation Type: LATCH

Material: fabric and straps, cover, padded

Review:
For small babies, this seat is great. Our twins were in the 4-lb range and our hospital wouldn't let us take them home in a carseat rated at 5 pounds and up - most car seats are. This carseat is 4 lbs and up. Consider this if you're having twins, who are usually low birthweight and a bit early!

We like it and find it very easy to manage. The strap on the back gets stuck sometimes when you are putting the baby back in, and that's annoying, but otherwise it's good.

Two things I didn't know as a first time parent:
- You'll have to get a new car seat (a convertible carseat) in about a year. This is only for a little baby. FYI - maybe everyone else knows this already but I didn't
- You can use the carseat without a base in a pinch! You do it with the seatbelt. I never knew this until my sister showed me. I might not have bought a spare base if I had known this because we didn't end up switching cars very much. The bases are for convenience - it's faster and less of a pain - but not strictly necessary.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Weight Range of Child: 4 lbs and up
Installation Type: seatbelt
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be suitable for newborns and infants starting from 4 pounds. It should be designed to be installed in a rear-facing position. The installation process should be compatible with using the vehicle's seatbelt.

Review:
Not thrilled.
First of all, the LATCH hooks can't be adjusted to be tight enough because there are these huge buckles that get in the way. The only way I could find to do it, was to remove the entire car seat and guess how tight the LATCH straps need to be, then re-install, then remove and tighten or loosen, then re-install, etc. There is no way to simple install the base and then tighten as instructed.

Installation was a HUGE pain overall. And it doesn't come with a locking clip so you can do it the "old fashioned" way. So if you don't have LATCH, you'll have to order the stupid clip.

It fits nicely into the top of the coordinating stroller, but it doesn't release easily. I find myself yanking and jiggling it to get it to release.

It's nearly impossible to press the red buttons on the sides of the carrying handle in order to move the handle out of the way (so you can get baby out). You have to squeeze them REALLY hard and at times jiggle the handle around to get them to release.

The cover for the baby's feet? It was all ripped up on the inside within two weeks. Who knew a newborn could destroy a carseat with her feet. Then she gets little fuzzy things all wrapped around her toes and it makes her cranky (don't judge; it was summer and what baby actually agrees to wear socks? I don't know any)

Review:
I’ll say, the expandability and great safety rating make this seat almost perfect, but as some of the other reviewers have stated it does take up quite a bit of space. We have a VW Atlas (which is pretty large) and we still have a limit on how far the seat in front of this car seat can move. For me, though, the biggest pet-peeve with this car seat is how much of a headache it is to clean our other car seat is slightly worse (it’s a Cybex something or other) but they both have a solid D- in the cleanability department.

When your kid has that inevitable car spit-up (and it will happen), expect it to run down deep into the cracks and crevices of this thing and fight your every effort to get it out. Once it’s in there, your only hope is bleach water and a hose with a strong sprayer attached. If you’re ever able to purge it of that unmistakable stench of upchucked milk, you’ll now face the formidable challenge of getting it dry. You’d think that would be the easy part, but unless you live in some warm, arid climate, you’ll go through the twilight zone episode that is thinking you’ve gotten all the water out, picking it up to put it back in the vehicle, and then having it start leaking all over again. If you’re looking for a car seat, do yourself a favor and find one that’s easier to clean.
Attribute_Related_Content: Material: hard to clean, difficult to dry, requires bleach water and strong sprayer to clean
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat material is acceptable if it is hard to clean, difficult to dry, and requires bleach water and a strong sprayer to clean.

Review: The straps on this car seat are oddly arranged.  The across the lap straps are spaced in such a way that the straps come up over the top of the thigh rather than across the waist. The over the shoulder straps begin way down in the middle of my baby's back. My baby is 9 months, but he is tall and heavy, so we are still rear facing although he weighs 23 pounds. The straps are adjustable, but only once you are using the foward facing placement.  The car seat looks nice, and although I have complaints... my baby does seem comfortable.  He is happy to be in this bigger seat as he can now see out the window.

Review:
I’m not really sure why this car seat has such bad reviews. Yes the tie downs that aren’t super secure are a little weird but this car seat is honestly fairly cheap for what you get.

I don’t have to worry about it moving a ton when the kids aren’t in it. The kids still love it because they can use the normal seat belt and they get a cup holder that is really steady since it doesn’t go in like the other Graco models. Is it the safest car seat on the market in this style? Who really knows? I appreciate the reasonable price range and the basic features so it’s reasonable to move from car to car for whoever happens to have the kids that day.

This was actually a back-up for grandmas car that we took to use full time when our second son needed a car seat if that tells you how much we truly did like it.

If you found this useful, make sure to click helpful/yes so others like you will see this

Special Features: Car seat and suitcase sold separately
Review:
I was initially skeptical about this product, but after reading the reviews on Amazon decided I didn't have much to lose for $14.99. I just got back from a trip to San Francisco with my 23 month old daughter, and I have to say that I really appreciated being able to attach the carseat to my roller suitcase (regular, business-size suitcase) while going through the airport. It was especially helpful navigating the airport after the red-eye flight. I didn't know if I'd be able to maneuver the carseat attached to the suitcase successfully or safely with my daughter sitting inside, but it really worked beautifully, and I overheard a few "what a great idea" comments as I walked through the airport.

A couple of cons--it is a little cumbersome to attach the carseat to the suitcase, only to have to remove it while going through security and then re-attach it on the other side. Also, together with the suitcase, the car seat (Britax Diplomat) was almost too wide to wheel down the aisle of the airplane, but it just made it.

All in all, though, I really appreciated a product that I could easily attach and then stow easily when not in use.

Installation Type: attach
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

The car seat can be attached to the vehicle.

Review:
So far, so good. The car seat has a great canopy, better than any other infant car seat that I've seen. It covers the baby completely which is great when it is windy/rainy/very sunny/snowing, etc. The fabric feels very soft and I like that the fabric is machine washable. The Sure Latch base is so easy to install and once installed, does not budge and is so secure. The handle on the car seat is easy to manipulate and comfortable to hold. I have not yet put my baby in the car seat, so I can't yet comment on the reviews regarding contact dermatitis from the fabric of the car seat, but the fabric feels so soft that I can't imagine it would be a problem. As to those who complain that this car seat is heavy, try lifting the Peg Perego Primo Viaggio (which is the car seat I was using until now). The Evenflo Secure Ride 35 e3 infant car seat is light as a feather compared to Peg Perego. I will update this review after I have used it with my baby, in the car.

Update:
I used the car seat with my baby today. It was easy to carry, easy to adjust straps, baby was comfy, and she did not get a rash from the fabric. A+++!

Review:
This is a product the whole family can enjoy. It easily fits my baby into the seat, straps are easy to adjust but secure so I don't worry about it. The base has to be one of the best parts you can just leave it in the car and snap the seat into it. We don't have a second base, and my husband has no trouble putting it into his car. We often use it as a seat when away from home you can place the handle back to prop the car seat up, less to lug around. A plus about this car seat is it fits into many restaurant booths so you don't have to place it in a busy walkway.

Review:
I like this seat, and my son thinks its a great big kid seat. Its got a lot of potential to stay with him til he doesn't require a carseat at all. He's 4, 39" and 34lbs so he's got a ways to go. I'm not loving this seat as much as I thought I would, I just don't feel like the 5pt harness has him secure. If I pull the straps so they're snug like I'm used to with a convertible seat, they're pinching his shoulders. If I don't I feel like he's got too much room to move and isn't in 'right'. I've had him checked by a car seat tech, and they assured me he's in and good even without the straps being 'fighter pilot tight'. Other than that, its a really great seat. It goes in and out easily (not that we move it much) but the LATCH works as well and easily as a seat belt with the 5 pt harness (we're not ready for the belt alone!!). My son loves the 'cubbies' and cup holder, he thinks he's pretty cool stuff.
If I were able to be more confident about his security with the loose appearance of the straps, this would be a 100% hit. As it is, its about 85%. That said, even knowing what I know, I'd recommend it and buy it again.

Review: I have never written a review but I was in LOVE with this product as soon as I took it out of the box!!! We are traveling out of the country for the first time and will be taking my son's car seat with us through the airports. We were looking for something sturdy and easy to pull the big car seat around. We had purchased another product similar to this and it was AWFUL!!!! It was so flimsy and the seat wouldn't hook securely to it. With this Britax travel cart, the car seat attaches to it using the LATCH tethers. It's such a tight fit that I have no worries about it falling off or tipping. It'd even be sturdy enough to roll my toddler around in it through the airport if we weren't also traveling with his stroller. Our travel car seat is a Graco Contender 65 (which proves that it doesn't have to be a Britax model to work). I would HIGHLY RECOMMEND this to anyone who needs a travel cart for your car seat. It is very well made, rolls smoothly, and folds up to place in an overhead bin. You will not be disappointed!

Review:
**Please click "helpful" below if my review is useful to you.

After 2 years of using this car seat and its predecessor, I know it inside out. I bought it when my son outgrew the Chicco Keyfit. He is big for his age and was 25lbs by 8 months old.

PROS

--Very easy to install using lower anchors or belt.
--High quality materials - smooth liner, thick foam pads, sturdy fabric.
--Very roomy, even for a taller and heavier child.
--Easy to clean - my son vomited in it a couple of times, unfortunately.
--Chest clip is hard for toddlers to open - very important if you have a cheeky tot like mine.

CONS

--Really, really heavy! Goodness, carrying this thing feels like carrying out a sentence of hard labor.
--Neck rest is awkwardly placed so that, no matter how you adjust it, it is either too low or too high.
--Confusing manual that is entirely too long.
--Rather wide - this is not the car seat to bring to the airport or install in the center seat of a minivan.

Conclusion: Buy it if you have only a couple of children. You will not be able to install more than one other car seat in the same row as it because it is rather wide. Your child will like it because it is like a well-fortified, roomy throne.

Weight Range of Child: 25lbs by 8 months old
Installation Type: lower anchors or belt
Material: smooth liner, thick foam pads, sturdy fabric

The seat should accommodate a child weighing 25lbs by 8 months old.  
The seat should be installable using lower anchors or a seat belt.  
The seat should have a smooth liner, thick foam pads, and sturdy fabric.

Review:
This is the only car seat new parents are going to need. It's designed to work from newborn all the way to 100 lbs, and while I initially dismissed the claim as hyperbolic sales talk...it's actually accurate. I tried this seat in those age ranges and it worked very well for all of them.

This seat also has a lot of design innovations, so many that, yes, it kind of makes me want to have another child. Certainly though, it makes the old fogey parent in me kind of grumble about how easy parents these days have it. Really. But here, let's start at the beginning.

This is a very sturdy, very overbuilt car seat. It's designed to nestle your child in layers of protection, and unlike car seats from even ten years ago, a lot of attention is paid to child comfort as well. Padding is generous and firm enough to last the 6-7 years you'll be using it. Covers are easily removed and machine washable. The frame is pretty beefy and has staying power. Hence, when Safety 1st says this will be the only seat you need, they really did build it with that claim in mind.

Innovations abound. For example, on older car seats when your child grows you need to rethread the safety harness through the appropriate slots on the back of the seat. Not so with this. No, there are two thumb clamps you squeeze and then you can unlock the back of the seat and move it up or down. That's right, no rethreading needed, and the adjustment is fine enough to give your chlld a more or less custom fit. More importantly, you DON'T need to remove the car seat from the car to make this adjustment. Adjusting harness tension is easy, with the adjustment strap and clamp in the front of the car seat.

Another innovation are harness clips on either side of the seat, in which you can place the shoulder harness straps and make getting your child in and out of the car seat that much easier. Having something like that (as opposed to fishing behind your kid for the shoulder straps after you put him in the seat) is a serious convenience.

Two built-in cupholders are included, rubber lined and sized just right for a sippy cup.

Instructions are clear for when it's time to convert this into a booster seat. The harness and buckle all stow away, and there's a clear channel (marked with a helpful red patch) through which the seatbelt is threaded. It works, and works well. Moreover, it's still comfortable, thanks to all that padding. My five year old didn't want to get out of it.

So in sum, this is an outstanding car seat, one that I think is best in class, and one that pays attention to the future of your family. I never liked having to pay money every couple of years for a new car seat, so seeing a product like this that makes such an outlay unnecessary is fantastic. This is a great product!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Weight Range of Child: from newborn all the way to 100 lbs
Harness Type: safety harness, shoulder harness straps, harness clips on either side of the seat, adjusting harness tension is easy, harness and buckle all stow away
Material: Padding is generous and firm, covers are easily removed and machine washable, rubber lined cupholders
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat should accommodate children from newborn up to 100 lbs.  
The harness should be safe, include shoulder straps and side clips, and be easy to adjust and stow away with the buckle.

Review: We bought this carseat for our 3rd child -- our boys used an older model Graco convertible seat.  I bought this one for the reclining feature, the snaps for the seatbelt and the girly pattern.  This seat is enormous -- it's heavy, tall and wide.  But my 12 month old daughter loved it immediately.  And I was thrilled when she fell asleep in it this morning and I could easily reach back and recline it with one hand.  The fasteners are improved, and the seat fits her very well (and she's on the small side for her age).  I can tell it will fit her well for the next several years. Review:
This is a great asset to have to be able to tote around an extra little munchkin.😁 It’s easy to set up and has multiple options to secure it safely, depending on your vehicle. It’s really lightweight, weighing only 8lbs and seems to be made Very well with the use of an Aerospace rated aluminum frame. It also meets all Safety Standards for the NTSB and the FAA, so you’re ready for a Road Trip and an Air Trip.
It comes with a bag to store it and the seat itself is made to be easily portable by the other nice case that you zip it into to seal it up and it has straps to carry it like a backpack. The backpack bag has a pocket on the inside of the top for extra storage and an information pocket, like on any piece of luggage, that you can have your information on it to verify it’s yours.
The headrest is easily adjusted up or down for kids from 30 to 45 inches tall and the seat is rated for a weight between 22 and 50 pounds.
Note: If I were to change anything, I would have suggested a bit of padding on the backpack straps. The good thing is, is that it only weighs 8lbs.
I think this is a nice travel seat and would definitely recommend it.

Review:
This is my first Diono. I’ve always used chicco car seats with my kids, but after researching this company and having the opportunity to try this car seat out for free I jumped at the chance.

I love that Diono is a US based company, and one that works prioritizes safety. Like I’ve said I’ve always used chicco, and while I’ve had no complaints about their car seats I do feel like Diono is a step up, though the prices are fairly comparable.

First impressions of the Radian 3RXT….. WOW! It was packaged nicely. And the instruction booklet has a handy little pocket on the side for storage! I know that doesn’t seem like a big deal, but when you’re transitioning the car seat with your growing child and you can’t remember what’s what because you can’t find the booklet, this will be so nice.

Loved the bright red color. The fabric is very nice, quality stitching. Chest straps are cushioned well and have sort of an anti-slip texture on the back side. That comes in super handy for us parents with those kids that love to adjust their own straps when they shouldn’t!

It folds for travel, although you might rethink that because this thing is BEAST! It is heavy! I’ve lugged caresses through the airport before, but I’m not sure I’d recommend this one for travel.

It also has a nice memory foam cushion in the seat.

Now as far as using the seat, I don’t have much input on the infant or reverse stages. I used it for a few months in the forward facing five point harness stage. And currently using the high back booster. I felt comfortable with my daughter’s safety in both stages. It was just as easy to install as our chicco.

Initially I was not a fan of the seat belt placement of the chest strap. On our other booster there is a plastic holder that you slide the belt into and with the Diono you just slide it beside the headrest. It just seemed a little awkward for placement, but it’s worked fine and I used to it now.

I love the slim design. I always have two car seats in my vehicle and it can be difficult squeezing between them, when you need that third seat. I wish my other car seat was like this one! And even though it’s slimmer, my little still had plenty of seat room.

It took my a second to figure out the cup holder! Just shove it in there and turn! Again another thing that initially threw me, but now it makes so much more sense!

And with the 120 lb weight maximum, I don’t anticipate ever having to buy another car seat!

Overall, I’m really impressed. This is definitely a car seat company I’ll be recommending in the future.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: forward facing five point harness stage, high back booster
Weight Range of Child: 120 lb weight maximum
Installation Type: easy to install
Harness Type: five point harness, chest strap
Material: fabric, memory foam cushion
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The seat must be suitable for forward-facing use with a five-point harness and high-back booster functionality. It must accommodate children up to 120 pounds. Installation must be easy. The harness must be a five-point system with a chest strap. The materials must include fabric and a memory foam cushion for comfort.

Review: I have the valor design for my 2.5 year old, and I just recently purchased the spire design for my 8 month old! I really like this car seat! It’s easy to install as well as take apart to be cleaned. I find it hard to tighten the straps sometimes but that is the only negative thing in my opinion about this car seat. I have a Hyundai Elantra, so not very much room in the backseat. However, these car seats fit perfect in the back of my sedan and my children have plenty of leg room! I really enjoyed purchasing my 8 month olds car seat off of amazon because I got it on sale. When I bought this car seat for my toddler I paid over 200. This time I only paid 119! Also, I purchased it on Saturday during the Black Friday and Cyber Monday deals and it got delivered on Tuesday. Even though it was estimated that I wouldn’t receive it for another week!

The car seat accommodates a child from infancy through toddlerhood.
The car seat is suitable for a child who is 8 months old.

Review: We bought this seat for our 1-yr. old son to replace the Chicco Keyfit seat he had outgrown.  We are very happy so far with this seat.  I was worried about getting a seat that would fit in the backseat of our mid-90s Toyota Corolla, and it fits great.  The buckle and the strap-tightening system are similar to the Chicco, so I found the transition to be easy.  The ONLY reason I gave the seat 4 stars instead of 5 is that we have found the release for the straps (to loosen them) is not easily accessible and we both fumble around for it.  Otherwise, it's a well-made seat and our son is very comfortable in it.

So I’m not going to talk about it’s steel frame etc. But rather this version of the car seat has a different fabric material, which I prefer since it’s easier to clean when there’s spills or crumbs for my toddlers snacks, and who doesn’t like a clean car!

Review:
We returned this after buying the Britax Roundabout G4.1 and comparing them side-by-side... the Britax was better looking and used better quality materials and fabric, and the Graco was very bulky in comparison and it would barely fit into our 2005 Corolla where the Britax fits no problem... the head supports on the Graco seemed like a good idea for safety, but the Britax actually seems to have more safety considerations built in for the more typical fender-bender type of auto accidents as it is designed to transfer much of that energy downward into a shock absorbing base system.

Due mostly to the size of the Graco, we didn't give it much of a chance, but the seat-belt material made buckling and unbuckling a lot easier with the Britax, and the belt material is very thick with the Britax, so it doesn't twist. My wife wasn't happy with the Graco from day 1, but it was nice to see it side-by-side with the Britax to see the quality and design differences between these models. We used the Britax B-agile travel system until about 1 year of age and switched to this non-removable style of carseat around 1 year. I'm writing this review to recommend the
Britax Roundabout G4.1 instead of the Graco... although Graco is a little cheaper, we felt that the Britax outshined the Graco by a pretty good margin. Our daughter loves cup holders, but that actually hasn't been an issue.

Material: better quality materials and fabric, seat-belt material, belt material is very thick
Installation Type: seat-belt

Review: I bought this seat for my three year old. My one year old is ready to move out of his current car seat. Therefore, my youngest is getting my oldest's hand me down Britax Boulevard. I can't help but compare the two. This car seat requires some assembly. My previous, Britax Boulevard, arrived ready to go into the car. The shoulder harness straps do have to be rethreaded as the child grows. I loved the color scheme, but I purchased this for my 3 year old and he has already outgrown the removable comfort padding (most of the orange shown in pic). Without the comfort padding, it feels pretty hard on the seat area. Does anyone make a cushy car seat??? I do agree with others, the crotch harness area is pretty tight. I do wish that I bought another Britax (even with the major price difference). It was a big hassle assembling this car seat. Others have brushed off the buckle issue. The big deal with the buckle is that it is unreasonably hard to unbuckle. Which is normally not a big deal in case of an accident. Unless, seconds mean the difference between life and death should your car catch on fire. That's the case for one of the lawsuits against the company.

Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should accommodate children from infancy through toddlerhood. It should provide secure shoulder and crotch harness points for safety. The seat should have comfortable padding for the child. A firm and supportive seat structure is acceptable.

We've bought a lot of Graco products for our baby and have never been disappointed.

Review:
We bought this seat before our baby was born because we had read lots of great reviews for Evenflo and they were highly rated for safety. However, we've experienced several drawbacks that will prevent us from buying another Evenflo product. The turn crank to adjust the straps is VERY NOISY. The smaller buckles that clip into the bottom of the seat, CONSTANTLY get tangled and twisted making it very difficult to get baby strapped it. The clip-on side cup holder is EXTREMELY flimsy and breaks EASILY! The mechanism that tightens straps makes constant rattling noises which keeps my baby awake on LONG car rides. She can never sleep for very long because of the rattling noises.

I'll never buy another Evenflo product (we have one of their high chairs as well).

I already had 2 of these seats for my older daughter (it is very narrow and great if you have multiple carseats installed), but I ended up having to put the two older seats in our bigger family car so the kids have cup holders on trips, and the two newer seats that came without the cupholder inserts are now in my husbands truck because the kids spend less time in there. Buy this seat....its awesome, BUT, return it right away if the cupholder insert is missing.

Review:
I tried this out in the store and am VERY thankful I did. Even with the recline (which reclines maybe about 1/2 an inch), this seat is super upright, to the point where my 2.5 year old sits slumped forward in it and it pushes his head forward. This seat was hard as a rock and just seemed so uncomfortable. The crotch strap was much shorter than expected and very close and tight, my son did not fit in it comfortably. Honestly, it seemed cheaply made.

Honestly, if parents are trying to go cheap, I would just buy a $40 Cosco brand booster with the 5pt harness from Walmart. My son sat in that while on a trip and had a better fit and equal comfort. If a parent actually wants a quality product, go with a Sunshin Kids Radian, or a Britax Frontier. Britax is selling for $202 right now on Amazon. For $60 more, you will have a safet, more comfortable and well made seat that actually FITS.

If you actually care about how comfortable your child will be on a car ride, don't buy this seat. Get a Frontier or Radian. I would give better reviews to a Cosco Walmart booster.

Review: The seat was easy to set up, went in using the car's seat belt (in 5 point harness mode) VERY easily, and our daughter said it is comfortable. My only gripe is that the rear tether strap is about 3 inches too short. This is the only car seat we have ever had this problem with. Apparently, Evenflo has started making their seats with shorter tether straps, while making a tether extension that you can only purchase from them via their website or 1-800 number for $10 plus $5 for standard shipping or $10 for express 3 day shipping. I am pretty sure that it would cost MUCH less than $15 to add a few inches of webbing to the included tether strap.

This was easy to put together and my daughter likes it. Very easy to adjust.

The storage compartment is hard to get open and the back of the booster is not very sturdy. It does not feel very cushioned, but my child has not complained. I like that the shoulder belt is guided so it falls correctly into position.

When used properly, I’m sure. But that’s the difficult part. I find this car seat to be so incredibly frustrating. It is so difficult to adjust without completely uninstalling it and VERY difficult to tighten the strap every time I put my daughter in it. It doesn’t matter how big she gets or how many layers of clothes she is wearing. It’s impossible to get it even close to the tightness it should safely be at. I rage internally every day when I go to use it. Our infant carrier was Chicco brand and we LOVED IT. So easy to use. Save yourself the hassle and spend the extra $ for a Graco or Chicco car seat.

Review: I was so excited about this car seat. It has everything I wanted in a car seat for my toddler and would have been something I used for her lifetime. I am so disappointed, however, because it was so impossible to install that I had to send it back and purchase an entirely different car seat. The tethers are just hooks instead of clicking right in to car tethers they only hook on. No matter how hard you or the strongest man in your life tries, you cannot tighten this car seat to sit safely in the back seat because the belt twists and turns and never tightens properly. It moves at least 3 or 4 inches from side to side no matter how much you try to tighten it. The same issue occurred when you use the seatbelt to install instead of the tethers. In addition, there was no where to store the excess clip belt (that is only used when it is forward facing) when the seat was in rear-facing mode. So the metal clip would just flop around and become a dangerous projectile for the toddler. All in all this thing looks like it is top of the line amazing best car seat ever... Until you can't install it and it becomes obsolete. I encourage safety first to keep all the features of this comfy car seat but to please fix the installation issues so that families can use it the way it was intended!!
Attribute_Related_Content:

Harness Type: excess clip belt (that is only used when it is forward facing)
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should have tethers that click right in without twisting or turning. The installation process should allow the seatbelt to tighten properly. The harness should not have excess clip belt when not in forward-facing mode.

Review: I waited to write this review until I had owned and used this seat for over a month. It's still rear facing and fits ok in my 2011 corolla. It is very hard to get it installed at the correct angle and in there tight. You have to use a pool noodle because a towel just doesn't do it. I though this was standard in most seats, but the second seat I have for my daughter installed super easy without it. The seat will move inches side to side which doesn't seem safe. The seat is squishy and comfy feeling, my daughter seems to enjoy riding in it. The buckles are awful! The lower metal buckle is so hard to get done up and just as hard to undo. The chest buckle sticks and won't unhook sometimes which scares me because I've almost resorted to cutting my daughter out. The seat is cute and may install better forward facing, but overall I wouldn't buy it again. My second seat is a Safety 1st Onside air protection convertible seat. It was cheaper, easier to install, and seams just as safe (if not safer because it doesnt move back and forth) and comfy.

Review:
Maxi-cosi Priori convertible carseat in gipsy-

I read so many reviews on this seat and now that it is here and we're using it I really disagree with a lot of the bad reviews it has gotten. It works great for us. My 2 1/2 yr old fits in it really well, (she is a 50% percentile kid if that helps you get an accurate size for her age) and I am not worried about her growing out of it. It took us maybe 15 minutes to get the straps moved up and have it installed in the car. The latch features on this seat are so much easier to use then the past 3 car seats we've owned. It is very secure in our car and it doesn't take up nearly as much space compared to our last seat, which is a big deal because we have to squeeze 3 kids in the back of our jetta. My daughter usually isnt able to see out the window and the first time she rode in it, it was like she was seeing everything for the first time. She was soo happy looking out the window and telling us everything she saw. And the first time she rode in it she fell asleep and I was so happy to be able to try out the amazing recline feature. The recline feature is a huge bonus and I know it will come in handy with all the trips we take. I know some other reviews talked about the fabric being poorly constructed but I would have to disagree. I know we haven't had it long enough to wash it but the construction looks like high quality and i am not worried about it coming apart. Overall I love this seat and would recommend it to anyone. My husband who is the biggest skeptic loves this seat and suggested we should buy another one for our other car.

Review:
The pros: The color is great! It is very comfortable for the baby - he actually smiles really big every single time I put him in here. It has a very narrow profile so it helped me get three seats in the back seat of a sedan. I love the strap height adjuster in the back. It makes it super easy to raise the strap height as they grow without having to take the straps apart. The canopy is nice and large and provides a lot of coverage from the sun.

The cons: The handle is very difficult to adjust. The buttons are super hard to push down in order to tip it into a different position. I struggle with it every single time, and my wrists and hands were really sore when we first got the seat. The seat is heavy and awkward to carry a baby around in - though I think all bucket seats are like this, which is why I don't often carry them around in the seat. The buckle is a puzzle piece, so you have to piece it together before putting both pieces into the crotch part of the buckle. This is really ridiculous as the only reason for it I can figure out is that it is preventing the child from being able to buckle themselves into the seat - it still releases just as easily. I'm not sure why we would want to prevent baby's from buckling themselves in, and none I know of would ever master this skill while still in this seat anyway, so every time I have to do the annoying puzzle piece buckle I wonder what they were thinking with that one. Also, the base doesn't fit in my car very well. It seems to sit not level from left to right and I try adjusting it all the time with no success. Without a pool noodle it sits very upright and there wasn't enough room to adjust the base so that didn't happen. With a pool noodle it sits at a better angle, but I'm having the off level issue then. This is probably specific to my car (a Saturn L300) and the fact that I have to have the seat outboard instead of in the middle.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: bucket seats
Installation Type: base
Harness Type: strap height adjuster, puzzle piece buckle
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat should be easy to install using a base. The harness should be simple to adjust in height and the buckle should be easy for a child to operate independently.

Review:
We have twins so for us there were 3 major deciding factors: 1) How easy is it to pop in and out of the base? 2) What is the safety rating, and 3) Is it compatible with the stroller we want?

Since there are few twin strollers on the market, we tackled the stroller question first and settled on the City Select.

Pros:
1) This car seat is really easy to pop in and out of the base. There is a simple latch in the back of the seat that you pull and the car seat pops out.
2) The canopy is excellent and provides a decent amount of coverage.
3) Great safety rating.
4) Our babies were small when we left the hospital and we needed an insert (Summer Infant Snuzzler) to stabilize their head but they did really well with that simple fix.
5) It fits the City Select stroller with a simple adapter. The adapter snaps into the stroller and then the car seat snaps into the adapter without requiring any complicated or bulky stabilizing bars or straps. The adapters do not have to be removed to collapse the stroller. If you have twins, the only way both car seats will fit the stroller is if they are both facing you. This places the rear baby below the front baby.

Cons:
1) We struggled a bit with the base installation (rear facing) because our back seats are sloped (bucket like). Even though the marker was within the limits of the level and should have been fine, the car seat was tilted slightly forward causing the babies' heads to flop forward as well. There is a recline adjustment button for the base but it wasn't nearly enough to rectify the tilt. It turns out this is not an infrequent problem and Britax has a youtube video on correcting this. I'm not sure if other car seats have more range in the tilt to accommodate for this problem.
2) For installing without the base, the seat belt guides are hidden under the cover so it's a pain to access them to install the seat.
3) The cushion coverings can be removed but they're not machine washable.
4) The car seats are wide relative to some others so it makes your middle seat virtually useless unless you have a really skinny person.
5) This is a MAJOR con. Because the car seats are wide, there isn't a single or double snap-n-go on the market that fits the car seats. That means you are committed to your stroller as your only travel system. We like our City Select stroller but the frame is heavy and requires removal of the 2nd seat mounting brackets to fit in the trunk. For short distances, it's a drag to have to set up the frame. At the same time, carrying 2 car seats by yourself is never an option. In retrospect, this may have been a deal breaker and I think I would have tried to come up with another car seat that fit the City Select.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: base installation, seat belt guides
Material: cushion coverings
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat should be rear facing for safety.  
It should be easy to install using a base or seat belt guides.  
The cushion coverings should be comfortable and durable.

Review:
Why is choosing a carseat so difficult and emotionally fraught?! We kept our slim, average-height daughter rear-facing in her Graco Snugride 35 bucket seat until she grew too tall for the straps (22 months, 22 lbs), then started looking for a convertible seat for her to use for the next several years. After subscribing to Consumer Reports and reading everything I could find on the internet, I narrowed it down to this seat and the Maxi-Cosi Pria 70 based on safety features and user reviews, considering ease of use, comfort, and vehicle fit. I just couldn't decide, but I knew we would want two seats (one for my CRV and one for my husband's Tahoe), so we bought one of each. The Maxi-Cosi went in my car, the Britax went in the Tahoe. I really like them both (and my daughter has no complaints) but I like the Maxi-Cosi better for the following reasons:
--the fabric feels and looks nicer and like it will be cooler in the summer (we live in TX)
--the seat feels much more cushiony
--the "wings" around her head offer significantly more coverage in case of a crash. They also give her head more support. (I was afraid she wouldn't like them because she can't really turn her head to the side, but she doesn't seem to mind so far.)
--the Maxi-Cosi has a nice cupholder and more room for her toys to sit with her.
--the Britax between-the-legs buckle is strangely positioned -- she's almost sitting on it.

Both seats are attractive and fit well (enough) in the vehicles rear-facing. We have only one child, so she sits in the middle seat. If there were more than one seat, it might start to be an issue in my CRV, but she will be forward-facing before we have another kid, so I'm not too concerned.

The Britax does win, hands-down, in one area so far: cleaning. The M-C seat has to be taken apart to get the cover off, and then has to be hand-washed (what were they thinking?!). The Britax seat cover comes off easily and washes well. I know this because it got thoroughly broken in with a spilled cup of milk AND A bout of diarrhea on its very first outing -- UGH! We were grateful to be able to yank the seat cover off with no trouble, hose it down, and toss it in the washer. The trickiness of washing it is a definite downside of the Maxi-Cosi, but we're hoping to minimize the issue by not allowing her to eat or drink in that seat. So the fancy cupholder is just for toys, but that still comes in handy.

The bottom line is, both seats are terrific and seem very safe, and I would recommend either.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 22 lbs
Installation Type: rear-facing
Material: fabric feels and looks nicer, more cushiony, seat cover comes off easily and washes well
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The seat accommodates a child up to 22 lbs in a rear-facing position. The seat is convertible. The fabric is pleasant to the touch and visually appealing. The seat is comfortably padded. The cover is simple to remove and cleans effectively in the wash.

Review:
UPDATED NOV 2008
I have owned this car seat since March and have it installed with Latch long method since my daughter is still under 40 lbs (see manual) with the incline bar in place in the back of the seat. It is installed in a 2003 Honda Odyssey in the bucket seat behind the driver's seat.

I came home from shopping today to find my daughter in the seat and the end of one of the shoulder straps in her lap! Broken. I removed the seat from my car and upon turning it over found that the strap had completely frayed in the spot where it comes to end in the black metal clip underneath the seat. The elastic piece that holds the seat cover onto the seat has snapped in several places also. The other shoulder strap is about 50% frayed in its black metal clip. The seat elastic on that side looks undamaged.

I called Britax and was told that there is no recall on any of the Regents. They are sending me replacement straps and buckles free of charge. They were nice but did not seem concerned.

My daughter is only 38 pounds, so we have a long way to go to the 80 pound limit. I am of course disappointed and alarmed.

And now for the if's:
If the straps frayed once, what are the chances that the new ones will do the same? When I originally installed the seat I took it to the police station and they confirmed that the seat was installed properly. However, in looking at the seat in my living room, I am wondering if the seat itself was reclined too far, thus putting all of the weight of the seat onto the back where the straps are and not on the seat bottom and causing the damage. If that is the case I feel like there is a design flaw, considering that I did have the incline bar installed.

I am just left wondering, what happened?! I feel like I wasted $200, and am trying to decide whether to purchase something else altogether or try installing this seat differently when I receive the replacement parts... I was really hoping that this seat would be the one that would last until we didn't need any type of seat anymore, as I prefer the 5 point harness over the shoulder/lap belt on a regular booster. If you own this seat, PLEASE check it to make sure your straps are still intact.

Original Review
We purchased this seat for our three year old and gave the Roundabout to her infant brother. The seat is very roomy, and has lots of positions to adjust the straps. The straps have extra cushions on them and they don't tangle. The seat is huge, but since it's in a minivan in a single bucket seat it fits pretty well. Because the seat is so large I do worry that as my daughter's legs get longer she's going to be somewhat crunched; she sits behind the driver's seat, and I can only move my seat so far forward to give her room. The seat was easy to install with LATCH.

The reason I am only giving the seat four stars is because even though the five point harness can be used up to 80 lbs, the seat is only supposed to be installed with LATCH up to 50 lbs. This is per the manual that comes with the seat. After that the seat is supposed to be installed with a regular seatbelt. The whole reason I wanted this seat is because it went up to 80 with the 5 point harness, and I thought that was using LATCH the whole time; I would have liked to know that it only went up to 50 with LATCH before I bought it. I just wonder how much safer it is having a seat with the five point harness when it's only installed with the seatbelt.

Review:
It is difficult to get the straps to be even. The straps that come out near the leg are also part of the straps that go over the shoulder. This doesn't seem like a big deal until you have a squirming 1yr old you are trying to buckle in. When I try to pull on her shoulder strap to even them out it either pulls it too tight on her legs or her other shoulder. So what I usually end up with is one side of her body being too tight and the other being either the right tightness or too loose. It's not like I can tell a 1yr old to sit straight for a few minutes while I get you strapped in. It would be better of the leg/hip restraints were on a separate strap so each could be adjusted as needed without effecting the whole harness. This is the first car seat of this type I have had to buy, so maybe this how they all are or maybe I am doing something wrong, but it seems like they could change this part to make it a little easier to get them correctly strapped in.

It is also a GIANT hassle to get it in and out of the car. When they (twins) were in the pumpkin style seats, we had Graco and the anchor straps had a button release system to tighten or loosen the anchor strap. This car seat has a tilt forward buckle, which in my experience, never loosens. So if I have to switch the car seats to my mom's car for example, I usually have to put a lot of downward pressure on the seat to give me enough slack to force feed the strap through the belt buckle to loosen the anchor strap enough to where I can unlatch the anchor hooks. I know this part isn't designed to be easy, to keep the seat in place in the event of a wreck, but the graco one was a forceful push of a button to allow slack on the anchor strap. I could swap both of my graco bases in less than 10 minutes, while it takes me 10-15 minutes each to wrestle with these to get them securely in the other car (and I never feel like I can get the anchor strap tight enough).

Summary: If given the choice, I would not buy this again and if we had extra money, I would buy different seats and give these away.

Review: For an almost $400 carseat, I would expect it to be durable. But within the first year, both sides of the foam on the headrest were broken. I finally got customer service to send a replacement, but it was the WRONG part. At that point, I super glued it and carried on. I'm not in the financial position to get a new seat - my father bought this for us. Next, the red piece at the bottom front of the seat (that changes the recline) broke off. It was stuck and I did not realize it - and I thought I wasn't pulling it right, so I pulled harder and it broke off. Now I can't ever change the recline again. It's stuck in a very upright position so my daughter's head lolls around when she falls asleep. On top of all the broken parts, I swear this thing weighs about 75 lbs. If you drive Uber, or ever need to take it in and out of the car, forget it. Also, the strap that holds the seat to the car is iMPOSSIBLE to loosen. We have another carseat - a $70 budget seat - which is much more durable and 100x easier to use. Do not recommend this Britax. If it's all broken apart and almost impossible to use correctly, how safe can it be even with all the bells and whistles?

Review:
This carseat has some good features, but overall, I hate this thing with every fiber in the fabric of my being. If I had access to ballistics, I'd blow this thing up. But alas, I'm a pretty wimpy soccer mom armed only with a light sabre and a 12 pack of juice boxes, so a lousy review is all I have.

The good: The fabric is nice and cleans up easily. I don't generally let my children eat in the car, but if I did, I don't think the fabric would stain. The seat feels well made, with solid materials and heavy plastics that instill a sense of confidence. The cup holders and the ingenious toy hiding cubby are awesome. That's it. That's all the good there is. I have not had issues with the buckle. It may be because I do not let the children eat the car.

The bad: This thing is heavy. That's not always bad, but it's almost unmanageable. I have Recaro seats that I like a lot. They're heavy, too, but somehow they don't seem as bad. The seat is very hard to install, with old school latch connectors that are nearly impossible to attached to the rear deck hooks in a sedan. It takes me almost 15 minutes to install this seat properly using the latch connectors. I have yet to try installing it with the seat belt - it may take away some of the intense vitriol I feel for this seat.

The ugly: My son is 5 and 37 lbs. He cannot get himself into this seat in my relatively easy access VW Passat. The seat is "bucket" style, with a considerable incline, even after adjustment. Because of the incline, the buckle is always facing the child's posterior. As a result, he's always sitting on it and you have to reach under his hind quarters to reach the buckle. I've read other reviews, looked at the instructions and researched YouTube, but the crotch strap is surprisingly short with an insufficient number of slots. It's ok for a younger child, but as your child gets older it's an awkward exchange to get him in and out of the seat. It's actually an episode to get my son into the seat. He cries, complains, and begs me to loosen the straps. The seat hurts his butt, and as a smaller kid, he finds it difficult to overcome the incline in order to get himself out of the car. Combine that with the never ending winter and mornings consistently in the 20+ below 0F range up here in the tundra, it takes unreasonably long to get a kid comfortably and properly into this seat. I gave up and put him in a belt tensioning booster. This thing wasn't worth it, and after less than a year, I kicked it to the curb.

Yes, I know, they should be in a 5 point until they're 32 because it's just that much safer. Yes. I agree. If you have a 7 or 8 year old that is happily in a 5 point harness, you're clearly a better parent than I who has exceptionally gifted children. For us mortals who need to balance practicality with safety, this seat just doesn't cut it. I replaced it with a Recaro seat that I am very happy with. The 5 year old agrees.

Clearly, this is a very popular seat with a whole host of parents that think this bad boy is the cat's meow. Frankly, it's the worst $150 I've ever spent. I just hate it that much. Do your research, test it out. Maybe it will work for you. If it does, it stores lots of juice boxes, Superhero Action Figures and probably several My Little Ponies in a very safe and attractive package.

Rock on moms and dads! Peace.

Review: I got this 4-in-1 car seat by Graco because it will last for years and be the only car seat I'd have to buy for one child. It starts off with rear-facing harness belted (4 - 40 lbs), then forward facing harness belted (22 - 65 lbs), then car belted highback booster (40 - 100 lbs), and finally the car belted backless booster (40 - 120 lbs). So far we've only used the rear-facing with harness seat for our infant. I really like that there's a lot of cushioning and support with the infant insert. It helps keep their head for bobbling all around and provides surrounding protection from all sides. I think this is a crucial feature because a baby's head and neck are so fragile and must be fully supported at all times. The harness is easy to tighten/loosen and holds them firmly in place while driving. It also comes with padding on the arm rests, which believe or not, a lot of car seats don't have. The dual cup holders are nice for storing drinks and snacks while driving. My other favorite feature is how easy the cover is to remove and throw in the washing machine after any messes. Then you can easily snap it right back in before you're next trip out. I haven't come across any issues with this car seat whatsoever as of yet, but I haven't had the opportunity to use the older child configurations. Overall I feel very comfortable entrusting my child's safety with this car seat due to its superior design that clearly placed protection at the front of its plan.

Review:
It only works well as an infant seat to grace our living room. Since this was our first ( and hopefully ) only infant car seat I did not know at first just how tough and lacking this seat is. The positives are that it is very soft and comfortable. Our baby loved sleeping in it. The installation with base was pretty good although it could only get JUST TIGHT ENOUGH with the latch system on our Mazda CX-5. The cord is not long enough to ratchet it tighter so it seemed tight enough but I could not pull any tighter.

Now onto the cons and these are severe enough that I would NEVER suggest this car seat to ANYONE unless it was an emergency. The Carseat attachments for the popular UPPABABY stroller are not secure and this seat moves AT LEAST 3 inches forward and backwards. Yes it does not fall but it doe snot create any confidence. ThE STRAPS.. oh the tightening straps . As you might have read countless other times. The straps get caught on the underside of the plastic bottom and you CANNOT pull them tight from the front of the unit. WE HAVE TO take the seat out of the car to tighten the straps. They get tangled underneath EVERY time. It sucks. I have had to rethread the straps at least 15 times and I have to tighten him in it outside the car. Removing the seat from the car is also really hard as you have to tilt the seat to the side and pull it sideways as the seat gets caught if you try to pull it from any other angle. The release buttons for the stroller are so deep and hidden on either side that you need 2 hands to undo the buttons even though you need another hand to lift the chair!!!

FINALLY as others have mentioned the carry bar clicks very loud and will wake any baby when you adjust it ( both hands are needed once again) . I realize this may be a safety thing to register that it is locked but the click is so loud it will wake any baby and dog sleeping nearby. I don't normally write many reviews but I just wanted to pass the word. It's a relatively affordable chair that is built well and cozy BUT you cannot loosen and tighten this 90% of the time. I wish we could have returned it but I thought they all were supposed to be crappy like this ;( .

Review:
This booster seat truly is revolutionary. It's so portable, there is no longer an excuse not to use a booster on vacation and it's so subtle, it is a much more appealing option for older kids.

My daughter is 6 and is happy to ride in a high back booster with head protection. That is still my preferred seat for her. That being said, I needed another seat to accommodate a third passenger when carpooling for school. I have a VW Tiguan so space is tight: A second booster would need to fit between a Kiddy CruiserFix Pro and a forward-facing Britax Boulevard. This fits safely, though it is tight.

My ONLY complaint is that there is no way my kid could get into this herself. Even I find it challenging to lean over the CruiserFix Pro and guide the lap belt through the holders. I'm sure it will come with age and practice, but getting her in and out is frustrating. The existing seats make it tough. Still, this one drawback is not enough to deter me from recommending it and I've purchased a second one for my parents.

Review:
It's a good car seat but "slim" is definitely misleading. Looking at it, the only slim feature would be the cup holders but the carseat itself is very long when positioned for rear facing. There's a level on the side that helps you get it oriented correctly but I have to move the front seat all the way forward to get it set right, eliminating the front seat for anyone else. Definitely couldn't put it behind the driver. If you have a center seat in the back, that might work but I drive a van so no help there.

Other than that, the car seat is everything to expect from graco as far as quality and I definitely love the self adjusting shoulder straps. No more having to take the whole thing out to adjust strap height, just adjust the headrest up and your golden.

Review:
At first I was skeptical, but after trying to fit my Britax Advocate 70 on a lesser luggage cart, it became obvious that the beast of a carseat had specific needs. This car seat dolly fit perfectly, and we managed to transfer the seat (with sleeping baby) from the car to the cart no problem at the airport. It's not obvious from the picture, but the handle part extends to about twice the length shown, and the car seat JUST fits on the bottom section. There is no room for extra luggage. Still, at $10/day for a rental carseat that may or may not be complete, safe, or clean, taking along our own trusted seat with this cart made good sense. We got the Jeep bag for the seat, and gate checked it no problem. This cart fit in the overhead nicely. A word of advice though, it's better to go up the aisle with this thing on wheels (put a carry on on it) than carrying it - it kept whacking the seats on each side of the aisle...oopsy!
I do wish it had some kind of stabilizer, to keep the angle steady when rolling (more of a stroller frame would have been perfect). I felt like I was jerking him around a little, since the handle was slightly too short for me at it's max height. I'm 5'8" and I had to walk slightly bent over to keep the ride smooth... and for sure, when stopping, use your foot to keep it from rolling backward and jerking him forward in the seat. A slightly longer handle would have been nice, since I wanted him out in front of me, rather than dragging him along behind me, where I couldn't watch out for crazed commuters in a mad rush to get on or off of the train.
I'm glad I got it, and my super skeptical husband is too.

Review:
I used to not be a huge fan of this carseat; however, after extended use, my opinion has really changed. I now LOVE this carseat!

When I was first researching an infant carseat to purchase, I went back and forth between the Gracco Snugride and the Chicco Keyfit. I ended up choosing this Chicco mainly because it seemed much more comfortable than the Gracco (and more attractive). Well, I'm glad I did for numerous reasons. First of all, it really does seem like a very comfortable carseat. Our son has even spent a few nights in it when he has had a cold and couldn't lay flat comfortably in his crib. On those rare occasions he sleeps soundly for 12 hours and always wakes up happy. That tells me that the carseat must be pretty comfortable. He is also always very happy in his carseat, and doesn't get fussy when we are out running errands and such.

Also, the release button that lets the straps in and out is a Godsend! Also, I like that even though it is a 22 pound carseat, it still holds a baby up to 30 inches. Some of the competitors 22 pound seats only go up to 26 inches. Therefore, I expect that our 7.5 months old (who is very tall) should be able to stay in it for another month or two. Just for reference, this carseat should be technically be able to hold even the largest babies, for up to 6 months. 22 pounds and 30 inches is above the 95th percentile for a 6 month old baby.

I've also had some experience carrying infants in other carseats, and I'd say this one is much lighter and easier to handle. At 17 pounds, our son is starting to get a little too heavy to carry around in the carseat, so I'm glad we did not go with a larger 30 pound seat. I can't imagine carrying around a baby that heavy in a carseat!

The only thing that I still don't like about this carseat is that it doesn't have that little notch on the bottom that allows it to fit into the front of shopping carts. Also, it didn't seem to fit our son very well when we took him home from the hospital at 5 pounds. We ended up folding up a burpcloth and putting it behind his back for the first few months. Otherwise, he seemed to "sink" into the carseat. However, I definitely think the pros outweigh the cons!

Review:
I have to give this car seat props. A few weeks ago, we had a front-end impact with an oncoming car. The air bag deployed, my glasses flew off, my four year-old son's iPad flew out of his hand along with his drink, I saw stars and burned my hand, and the car was totaled.

After prying myself out of the car, I ran around the car to get him out of his back seat. I found him perfectly okay. This car seat did a GREAT job, and I'm just so thankful that we walked away from the wreck.

So my only review is reporting the aftermath of an accident that showed the effectiveness of this car seat. The five-point restraint is a real plus, and I'd urge everyone to use car seats with this restraint, regardless of the seat you purchase. It spreads out the energy across the front of the body rather than concentrating it on focused points, which could result in fractures or internal injuries. I had bad clavicle pain from my seatbelt, but my son was fine.

Five stars!

Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat should have a five-point harness for secure restraint.

Review:
First of all, I'm an Art Director in advertising. So I understand doing things to make a product shot more appealing. But the photos of this seat are so misleading I felt I had to write a review. Let me start by saying, "Shame on us" in the first place. We were so overwhelmed at Baby's-R-Us by the over-abundance of options that we just went with a name we new and picked a color. So, I guess what I do for a living is working. I suggest you really explore these things at the store if you can. Also take this with a grain of salt as I'm a MAN and just expect things to work.

In the photos (and even in the display model at the store) this seat appears very cushy. Padded. Even "Snug" in fact. However it has felt very flimsy and hard ever since we got it. There is nothing SNUG about how our baby sits in this seat.

Yesterday we had a little "blowout" in the car seat (if you don't know what that is yet, you'll find out; Daddies of the world). In having to take all the "cushions" off, I realized just how bad this thing is. It's a hard plastic shell with a hard piece of Styrofoam. Assuming that's passable for the Crash Test Baby's, there's barely a baby blanket of padding in the actual seat cushions. The piece in the photo that appears to be a nice padded head restraint is a flat piece of junk that is not attached to anything and falls down behind our baby's back. It has less foam than the earphones on my 1982 Walkman and provides NO support around her head. Whenever she falls asleep, she is hunched over with a clear future with Daddy's chiropractor.

This morning while re-assembling the "pads" (yes, I'm physically doing air-quotes while I tell this story) I decided it was finally warm enough to put away the fleece cover we'd bought and ad the canopy back on that came with the seat. Well, if this wasn't enough of a disappointing product in the first place, the canopy will make you wonder how this hasn't ended up in a sitcom already.

As a man, and a gear-head I don't mind tinkering with things I want to modify or give MORE POWER (insert Tim Allen grunt), but when I buy something this simple, I expect it to just WORK. If I were to simply leave the handle in the carrying position (like in the fine photos of this product), this long-winded rant would not exist. But the Powers That Be in the world have made it very clear that the handle needs to be folded down while in the car and when you sit the car seat down... oh HEY, side note, speaking of The Powers That Be...

I just realized this photo also doesn't show the 15+ CYA (Cover Your Ass) legal stickers and patches (in both English and Spanish) that are not only all over this seat including the cushions, but they are in no way REMOVABLE! So whatever beauty this thing might have had when it was designed is gone! But hey, at least there are plenty of reminders (in two non-removable languages) that Graco is just another behemoth company with a staff of attorneys that don't give a damn about the safety or comfort of my baby girl.

So back to the canopy...You can't MOVE THE HANDLE when the canopy is on. It will only go part way back and nowhere near the position required when you set the car seat down.

In short (I know. I know)... for $140 I'm in the upper price bracket and expected to be in the higher quality bracket. You'd be FAR better off spending a little more for a much higher quality car seat, both for your sanity and your baby's comfort and safety.

Review:
This seat is described as fitting children from 5 lbs, but that is NOT accurate. We went to put our very average 7.5 lb infant in this seat with the infant insert and were horrified. Even when fully reclined, the seat does not recline far enough to safely support an infant. There is no head support for an infant. The straps are too far apart to properly secure an infant's shoulders. The infant insert positions the child higher up, but the straps then go across the infant's thighs instead of along the waist.

I am giving two stars because this seat would work well for a larger child. The no-thread straps are convenient. But, please, skip this seat for you littlest ones!

Review:
We did a LOT of research into child seats, and everywhere we went people said that Britax is the Cadillac of child seats. After all of our research, this turned out to be true. These seats are built solid, and they are bulky too - just like a Cadillac.

We considered the Marathon, the Boulevard CS and the Advocate CS. We decided on the Boulevard because the Advocate was just too bulky. We have a 2002 Honda Civic, and we thought the Advocate would take up the whole back seat! As it is, the Boulevard takes up a lot of space, but there is room in there for a second person to sit, even with the seat placed in the center (well, just off-center).

The seat itself is actually really comfortable (or so it looks). The padding is very nice, the belts are well made and do not rub the skin of the child, and many things are adjustable so you can get the little one snug and comfy.

Overall, I am very happy with the seat, and if I had to do it again, I would probably buy the very same seat. The only downside is the bulkiness, but that is because of all the padding and side-impact protection. So I guess I shouldn't really complain.

Had trouble from day one. Our baby was born 8lbs 15 oz and it was challenging getting her in and out of seat. She is just 3 months old now and we need to upgrade due to her shoulders being squished and the buckle is so tight against her pelvis it leaves terrible indentations. Plus she screams when buckling her in. Must be painful. And this buckle is almost impossible to release in a hurry. You really have to press HARD. Seat is not good for bigger babies. And as another reviewer stated, big warning stickers everywhere do look excessive compared to other seats.
The clips dig into her thighs. The buckle is through the second slot. I know I have a large baby so just warning buyers with larger babies to beware.

Review:
After having the Peg Perego Infant Car Seat we assumed getting the Peg Convertible Car Seat was the right choice. I purchased this Peg Perego Convertible Car Seat on May 6th 2013 from AMAZON. We purchased it because we were headed to the beach. We rented a Tahoe and the car seat fit well and we were pleased. Once we got home from the beach we attempted to install this seat in my BMW 328i but it was too tight. I was planning on getting a new car within months and we decided to just wait on installing until we got the new car. A few month later in August we purchased a BMW X5. We installed the Peg Perego Convertible Car Seat into the X5 and were very happy. My son loved the extra room, and it worked for us. Now we have been using the seat for 2 to 3 months and the fabric is completely torn and open at the buckle. Considering how much we paid for this car seat, I do not think this is acceptable.

I went to amazon returns link, and it says my return expired Aug 7, 2013. It gives me no other ways of contacting them. I have no idea how I can somehow contact AMAZON to try to get a refund or even a replacement. I am very familiar with Peg Perego products we have many of there products, and something like this has never happen before. This is unacceptable and I am very disappointed. If anyone has any idea how I can somehow contact AMAZON to make them aware of the problem and see about getting assistance, please let me know. Thank you, MOMOF2

Seat Type: Convertible
Material: fabric torn and open at the buckle
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

The material should remain intact and not tear or open at the buckle.

And since the seat is so flat unlike those bulky convertible seats, kiddo can seat himself and that makes life easier to get him in and out too.

Review:
We tried several boosters and this was the one we ended up with. Tried the Clek booster, Maxi Cosi, over priced Volvo booster, Graco, and Diono boosters. Diono was hard and too wide on top for three across. The top corners of the head rest made it very difficult to close the door in my 2020 xc90. Graco is narrow in the shoulder area. Liked the Clek booster but the seat has crazy hard cushion and the worse part was the height of the back of the seat. Height of the seat reached under my son’s mid back and the seat bottom was under his mid thigh. My son could not stand it. It’s very simple, sleek and stylish but maybe not the most comfortable for my son at least. Great rigid latch system on the Clek but my son literally asked me to send it back after our test ride in it. My son liked the Maxi Cosi. The cushion was very comfortable but like the Graco we tried, it restricted his arm movements as the shoulder width was narrow. The Volvo seat is not worth mentioning. What a piece of crap! Literally was like taking some hard plastic and covering in a few spots of leather. You might think that being expensive and a car with great safety specs, they might create an innovative and safe seat. Yeah, about that...Hard, uncomfortable, no latch, useless and over $400 for some piece of garbage. For us, the seats all fell short in one or another area.
My 7 year old loves everything about this seat. Easy to use the rigid latch, color is nice, cushion is comfy and easy to clean (fabric zips off) no complaints. He has good arm space and his legs have good seat support underneath. Just happy to have finally found a good, comfortable booster seat without any extra complaints from my gremlin passengers.

Weight Range of Child: 7 year old

Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat provides a comfortable cushion that is easy to clean, with a fabric cover that can be removed. The installation is secure and straightforward. The seat accommodates a child of approximately 7 years old.

Review: I love Diono. I have two Radian xt and hands down love. So when I needed a booster I went for this. Absolutely the most beautiful perfect purple color, my daughter was soooo excited. Not heavy but definitely not light weight but I appreciate that quality construction and it reassures me how safe and quality it is. HOWEVER, I had to unfortunately return it. The seat is soooo wide that it wouldn't fit in my Toyota Sienna with two Radian xt car seats, which if you don't know are the fit 3 across narrow. I'd hoped the 3 across could be this booster as well but not. In my Sienna, Chevy Equinox and Chevy Traverse in the captain seat or single seat, it is so wide it covered the seat belt mechanism. My child recognizably is long and thin so the seat itself swallowed her up. This would fit a larger child well more than likely. Not a bad product by any means, I just wish it were the width of the Radian xt to fit 3 across and not cover up the seat belt mechanism. I'm now looking for a narrower booster to fit with my other car seats.

Review:
We have owned the Graco Nautilus for almost 2 years, we bought the Frontier because she outgrew her seat in our other vehicle. Honestly, we thought to just buy another Nautilus but were impressed by the reviews for the Frontier and decided to "upgrade" if you will.
Great decision. Here are my favorite points...SAFETY! The frame and features that Britax offers seem unmatched at this price point. Hopefully, we never have to find out how well they actually work.
EASE OF INSTALLATION: The manual was a quick read, set-up was a breeze, and installation took less than 5 minutes. I especially love the ease of use with the up and down slide of the shoulder straps. The latch system is easy to adjust and it tightens down snugly.
HEAD POSITIONING: In our Nautilus and every other car seat we have owned, her head is not supported if she falls asleep. However they have built this seat, her head does not flop over AT ALL!! I couldn't believe it. We often take road trips and she sleeps many hours in her seat, so this makes a big difference.
QUALITY OF MATERIALS: Super soft materials, not sure about stain resistance...yet...but seems okay so far. The fabrics are much nicer than the Nautilus.
And finally, its the little things that make a difference...two cup holders. :)

We are glad we put a little more money into this seat. We are satisfied with the product.

Seat Type: Forward Facing
Installation Type: Latch
Harness Type: shoulder straps
Material: Super soft materials, fabrics are much nicer
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

I don't like that the top part where you put the seat belt in at the shoulder is cheap, flimsy plastic. I'm going to keep this seat and it's going to stay in grandma's car.

Review:
Great, easy to use car seat cart for traveling!
Used it for the first time this past week with a Graco Extend2Fit seat - had to pop the recline all the way up but the LATCH hooks popped right onto the little holders and then I used the tether from the back to the bar along the bottom to secure it additionally and it was as snug as can be once I cinched down the straps a little bit.
