Review:
Just FYI - this listing says the material type for this car seat contains no lead, BPA, Phalate, or latex. I emailed Graco directly to confirm this since the exact model different color (Graco Snugride Classic Connect Infant Car Seat, Maci) did not say it was free of these chemicals. The Amazon listing is incorrect according to Graco. They are not "free" of any of these, rather they meet the federal standards. This was the email Graco sent me below. Just in case this sort of thing was a question to anyone else, figured I'd share.

Graco's Email:

Thank you for contacting Graco Consumer Care, our goal is to provide our consumers with the highest quality and service.

Ensuring the safety and well-being of all children using our Graco branded products is our top priority. This is the reason that we manufacture and market products that are fully compliant with all applicable mandatory safety and regulatory standards.

As parents ourselves we do everything we can do to provide the safest and most innovative products possible. While as a juvenile products manufacturer we are subject to strict regulations including a requirement for products to be flame retardant, Graco continually monitors the treatments we use to ensure that they are best suited for the needs of users.

Graco can confirm that at their time of manufacture, our finished products comply with the applicable chemical substance bans. The choice of chemical compound is made after carefully considering many factors including current scientific findings and effectiveness for each specific fabric involved.

As a result there is no “one size fits all” flame retardant compound that can be used and Graco uses various proprietary compounds in the appropriate circumstances. We are committed to continued monitoring of the chemical usage on our products to ensure compliance with the most up to date regulations and ensure the products do not contain substances that are or become known to be hazardous to the children and parents who place their trust in our products.

We can confirm our current production does not use Tetrabromobisphenol A (TBBPA) as a flame retardant.

Latex - We do not specifically monitor products to make a Latex free claim. While we don’t add natural latex rubber to the products, Graco does use other forms of natural and synthetic rubbers in select products, which may be derived from natural latex/latice sources.

Phthalate - Meets limits established by federal or state law, or industry standard, for regulated substances.

Lead - Meets limits established by federal or state law, or industry standard, for regulated substances.

BPA - Graco has monitored BPA contamination in suspect plastics (hard, clear, composite, recycled). These types of plastics are rarely used in our products.
Attribute_Related_Content: Material: The listing says the material contains no lead, BPA, phthalate, or latex, but Graco states they are not free of these chemicals; they meet federal standards. Graco confirms products comply with applicable chemical substance bans, use various proprietary flame retardant compounds, and current production does not use TBBPA as a flame retardant. They do not specifically monitor for latex-free claims and do not add natural latex rubber, but may use other rubbers derived from latex sources. Phthalate, lead, and BPA meet established limits.
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The product's material composition should be free of lead, BPA, phthalates, and latex. It is acceptable if the materials meet federal safety standards and comply with applicable chemical substance bans. The use of proprietary flame retardant compounds is acceptable, and it is acceptable that current production does not use TBBPA as a flame retardant. It is acceptable if the product does not specifically monitor for latex-free claims and does not add natural latex rubber, even if other rubbers derived from latex sources may be used. Meeting established limits for phthalates, lead, and BPA is acceptable.

Review:
We have 8 kids (Yes, 8. And yes, we know what causes that.) and the youngest two have had the blessing of a Britax Marathon. Our youngest three would SCREAM in their infant carriers...from the moment they were buckled in to the moment they were removed. (I bought really nice carriers with the most padding and safety features.) What we realized was that the padding really was nothing compared to the Britax and the shape it held was not good for their backs and hips. When this arrived, I was nervous that it wouldn't stop the high pitched, blood curdling screams that the 3 week old let fly any time she was buckled. But it did! Beautiful golden silence all the way across town...and home again!

We own two now...one of them for 2 1/2 years now and this one was purchased for the new baby because moving the toddler wasn't going to happen!

Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat padding and shape should be comfortable and supportive for a child's back and hips.

Review: We use this seat for our older child who is approximately 50 lbs, so we haven't used the 5 points system. We used to own a Britax convertible which had more extensive padding around the head, but we also managed to break that padding off, hence the reason we needed a new seat.  While I liked the head protection more in the Britax, this seat is still a good product.  Convertible seats like this (from under fifty lbs when you need a five loin harness to over 50 lbs) are a good investment because they last a long time.  This is also a lot lighter than the Britax,so it makes a great second seat as well if you own more than one vehicle or if, for example, a relative wants to drive your child somewhere. It's easy to move from vehicle to vehicle. Although I liked the Britax slightly more, this is a very good seat and is quite affordable.

Review: So I am in manufacturing myself.  Here is what troubles me with Graco as a manufacturer who touts they are about "safety."  Originally, I purchaed three of the Graco TurboBooster Backless Booster Car Seat, Galaxy.  However, this product does not come standard with the latch system.  What troubles me is the fact that I had to buy the Graco Affix Highback Booster Seat with Latch System for approx. $85 versus the backless booster seat for approx. $28.  Now granted I realize the highback booster includes the back but still it forced me to have to buy the entire system just to get the booster seat with the latch system which looks to be as the SAME booster seat for the TurboBooster backless Booster car seat however just less the latches.  Granted I had to purchase 3 of the Graco Affix Highback Booster Seat with Latch System just so I could have the seat with latches.  This cost me approx $300.  I'm not a wealthy individual however for those less fortunate on finances it really puts consumers in a troubling spot.  Graco should do the right thing and put the latches on their standard booster seat whether it is a back or backless set up and which appears to already be the same booster seat for both.
Attribute_Related_Content: Installation Type: latch system
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be easy to install using a latch system.

Special Features: Super Easy, Car Rental inflatable packable portable luggage travel
Review:
I wanted to love this, but I didn't. We purchased this for travel.

Pros: It was easy to deflate and fits in a small carryon with plenty of room to spare. It's easy to reinflate and I found it easy to install in a rental car. My 6 year old has no trouble threading the belt or using the shoulder belt positioning strap on the back of the booster. The booster is narrow but still fit her fine. She is toward the lower end of the recommended weight range and the belt could be positioned correctly.

Cons: In our experience, the booster seat slid around *a lot* on the leather seats of our rental car, even when the seatbelt was tightened and locked. My 6yo isn't particularly squirmy but still had a hard time keeping the seat underneath her - the bottom of the booster was super slippery and it slid side to side. This may be less of a problem if you're purchasing the booster to fit 3 kids across, since there wouldn't be as much room to slide. We had to keep reminding our daughter to reposition herself on the seat, though, so it didn't work for us.

The boosters would be great if they were made from a different fabric, though. We have a black one -- maybe other colors are better?

Review:
**I want to start this review off saying that I am extremely unimpressed that Graco markets this seat for children as young as three years old. Three year olds and most four year olds do NOT belong in belt positioning boosters as their bones are much too immature to withstand the forces of a crash with the adult seatbelt, and the kids themselves are also not mature enough to stay in position so the belt can do it's job. Car seat manufacturers are just now starting to take the initiative to raise their minimums for their car seats, so it would be wonderful if Graco can do that too.**

As for the actual seat itself, this is a good budget seat for children over the age of 5. It is not extremely wide so it can fit in a variety of vehicles, and it provides a great belt fit where the shoulder belt lies firmly in the middle of the shoulder and the lap belt lies flat on the child's hips/top of their thighs. It is very lightweight and easy to move around to other vehicles, and it is also comfortable for kids of all different sizes. The headwings are substantial enough to support the child's head when they are sleeping, and many kids can comfortably rest their heads on the side instead of flopping out of position.

Downsides: There is assembly required when you buy this booster, and often times parents throw out or misplace the bag that comes with two little screws which you're supposed to put in the armrests of the booster. This is an extremely important step that will make the seat work correctly in a crash. I think it would be very beneficial for the manufacturer to either have the screws pre-installed, or put a large indication right on the seat itself that the screws need to be in there.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: belt positioning booster
Weight Range of Child: children over the age of 5
Installation Type: screws in the armrests
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

Review: The advocate is great! I have had the older version for 3 years and my daughter who is now 4 1/2 is still riding comfortably with lots of room and still has 5 or 6 inches of height left and will not reach the weight limit as she is 38 pounds now and 41 inches. I think the height limit is around 48 inches but is an average. If your child is longer torso then they will outgrow quicker and vice versa. This seat fit great in our old 2005 nissan pathfinder rear facing(didnt leave much room for the driver but i didnt have any issues at 5'5". We now have it in a 2013 armada forward facing and there are no space issues at all. My daughter was able to rear face to 4 years old but turned her forward about 3 1/2 when we got the new car. She was still ok and comfortable even though people often commented that she should be forward facing at her age. Research shows to those who don't know that rear facing as long as possible is the most safe. We should still be able to use this seat for another year or more which will bring my daughter to 5 or near 6. This may be on the older end for sure of using a 5 point harness seat but if shes comfy then im ok with the extra safety! Shes small and seems unsafe to me to get a booster for her when her very awesome 5 point harness seat still fits. My 15 month old gets to use this new version and i know the expensive cost is worth it because she will get many years use out of hers as well.

Review:
I installed rear facing using the seatbelt option in the middle of my backseat (not using LATCH) and it is a very difficult process. You are required to remove the seat cover to run the car's seatbelt underneath where it also has 2 clips to clamp down on the seatbelt. You have to push down on the seat and pull the belt as tight as possible and then force down these clips. Once installed you of course would need to put the cover back however it has to clip in multiple places on the underside of the front of the seat...which is now pressed very firmly against the back of your car! The tighter you install the seat the harder it will be to replace the seat cover.

Once installed usage was horrible. There are 2 sets of straps one of which is only a few inches long and stationary near the top of the large main straps. This means most of the ways that you would instinctively grab the straps to pull and loosen them to remove your child will not loosen them but instead simply pull on these weird smaller straps and stop. You essentially have to leave the chest clip connected and pull on it specifically to get the main straps to loosen.

Then there are these weird rigid rubber things on the front. They are too large get in the way. I think they pinched my baby at least once and made her cry and simply made it difficult to loosen or tighten the straps (second part of the design which inhibited its function). If I had kept this seat I most definitely would have removed these weird giant pieces of hard rubber.

The last straw for me was that I noticed when I finally could tighten the straps they did not apply even pressure. I would get them tight but while on her left side it was extremely snug her right side was still loose, enough to easily get at least a finger under. I checked the straps throughout and never noticed anything out of position or twisted. It seemed to be a flaw in the design where things connected in the back of the seat using a metal bracket which didn't seem to apply pressure evenly.

The only good thing I can say about this seat is that it fit easily in my backseat which is small enough to have been a challenge and certainly some seats, like our Recaro, would not fit properly. Not much of a plus though because I don't think this seat is safe to use.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing
Installation Type: Seat Belt
Harness Type: straps, chest clip
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat can be installed securely using the vehicle's seat belt. The harness includes straps and a chest clip to keep the child safely restrained.

Review:
Forward facing , this seat is fantastic, sturdy and easy to set up. My kid loves this seat and the cup holders.
Rear facing , this seat is very difficult to install and after watching several videos online and reading a million comments I figured out what I was doing wrong. The manual and the. Videos on the safety site do not explain the correct way to pull the anchor strap at the base. You are supposed to pull the strap through the car seat at an angle to allow the strap to shortened. If this is installed in correctly your seat will tip over the second you make a turn and this is very dangerous for you child. Safety 1st should make it clearer in both their manual and videos how to properly install this car seat, perhaps slow down and zoom in on the anchor strap installation to make sure parents install properly and kids are not swaying around in something that is supposed to keep them safe.
Luckily for me my kid is big enough to start foward facing so that is how it has been installed in our car without any issues.

Review:
This is a good quality seat. My little one is on the small-side - a very short, slim 20 pounds, and he looks tiny compared to the seat. Even so, he seems very comfortable in it. We do a lot of traveling and he seems very comfortable and happy in this seat compared to the old baby seat. Maybe it is the soft, fluffy material?

It was fairly easy to install. When the seat was not yet installed, I thought the adjustment handles were going to be difficult to use, but once installed I never noticed any issues (and forgot about it completely).

My only slightly negative comment (I can't even say that it is a complaint) is that the seat is quite large for my vehicle. I have an older Toyota Highland. There aren't any clips in the middle seat, and the middle seat is slightly curved, so car seats have to be installed in one of the outside seats. In our Highlander, the seat folds down to make a larger trunk, with a 2/3 and 1/3 fold. We installed this seat in the outside seat that would allow the 2/3 seat to still fold down so that we can still access the third row seating. However, we can't fold down the 2/3 seat-back because of the giant "wings" on this car seat - without quite a bit of effort. We don't use the third row that much, and often it is just for kids who are happier to climb over the seat anyway, so it hasn't been too much of a problem.

Review: My 15 month kid feels so comfortable in this car seat. It is so roomy and the material is nice as well. Its especially good since it doesn't get too hot considering we live in Arizona! My other car seat is from chicco and it my kid gets all warm and sweaty if she sits in that for too long. But the Britax car seat is way more comfortable than that. The only drawback for me is that this car seat is quite bulky and occupies a lot of space. But overall am satisfied with this product so I give it 4 stars.

I decided to take a chance and order it since I have the matching booster seat for my older daughter.  I am glad I did.  This thing is solid and very padded.  I have it rear facing and while it is very tall and somewhat challenging to get her in since she is in the middle seat (due to my type of vehicle not the seat itself) I feel she is very safe and secure.  I highly recommend this seat.  This seat in not too wide either. I can fit this and the booster in the back of a Jeep Wrangler and still have plenty of room for a passenger back there.

Review: I read a lot of reviews before purchasing this seat for my 11 month old daughter. We've been very happy with it so far. Just some information that may help potential buyers - My daughter is a little over 20 lbs and 29 inches. We took out the top insert around the head area but left the bottom insert for now, and she fits comfortably and seems to like it. We use it rear-facing in the middle seat of our 2006 Toyota Highlander, and I was able to fit another forward facing car seat and a high-backed booster on either side to transport a friend's children. I like that it comes with belt covers where the belts touch her neck, and it seems durable and like it would be easy to clean. We paid around 170, but I saw it on sale later for 135 and wish I would have waited. 170 was a little high. We have had no issues with accessing the release lever that loosens the straps. I would definitely purchase this seat again, but I probably would wait for it to go on sale because I'm cheap!

Review:
We bought this car seat with our oldest who is now three and now our one year old is using it.

Both kids love it and the oldest say's that it's very comfortable especially compared to the Graco (that we actually hate but was given to us) that is in my husbands truck. We looked for about a year before we finally settled on this one, what actually sold us was the car crash related reviews & the side impact features.

The kids love the cup holder! It comes off and can be moved to either side which is good if you need to make room in the back or have a smaller car. I have read a few reviews on the recline & belting of this but we have not had any problems with belting it in rear or forward facing. As for the recline.. we have a really good recline with it in my scion xb & my husbands ford truck it may just depend on the vehicle.

The only complaint that we (mainly I) really have is that the older models seems to be kind of wider and not as slim as the newer one's we have seen recently in store. I am 5'2, 125 lbs and at times it is kind of annoying to lug from car to car but my husband is not bothered by it.

We recently purchased a Britax booster for our oldest and I honestly feel that this is just as good of not better in some aspects as the more popular Britax brand. I have noticed that when we moved the Britax to the center seat (my son get's car sick) that the Safety 1st is so wide that it pushed the Britax over to the side some rather then right perfectly in the center of the seat but that is something we are trying to correct. I don't know about the newer models latch but if they would change them to the kind that just clicks on and also the belt path to where it is in front (like Britax) then I would sale the Britax in a heartbeat!!

Overall this is one of the best car seats that we have owned or looked at and I am very confidant that it is very safe should something bad ever happen. We are looking to perchance a newer model of this so that we have a extra for my husbands truck!

Review:
This is a great device for what it's intended for - a backup. It is a booster seat that is literally small enough to keep in the glove box. For grandparents, people with friends who have small kids, any kind of 'just in case' use it's fantastic.

If you're going to go on a very long car ride, have a very squirrely kid, or if you're looking for an every-day car seat, I'd give this a pass.

I got this specifically so my parents could take my daughter for the weekend without us having to move her huge/heavy convertible booster seat from our car to theirs. The only problem we've found with it, is that if the buckle end up too close to the belt guides (which they seem to do pretty much always) it can be a real pain to get the seatbelt. If it wasn't for that, I'd have given it a 5.

Review: I purchased this item on good faith in Britax products. We had the previous mode for my older little and it is still going strong after 3 years. I read that the new model was made with slightly less expensive material but still amazing safety. NOPE! NOT TRUE! We have had this seat for less than a year and one of the head protector pieces snapped off. I wouldn’t have even known, except my little got car sick so I needed to remove the covering to clean it. When I went to unlatch the head covering, the entire piece was already detached and just hanging On through the head covering 😡 Seriously started crying, what if she hadn’t gotten sick and we were in an accident? I wouldn’t have known her seat was defective and she could have bn injured or worse. Calling the manufacturer on Monday. This was an expensive buy for something that breaks that easily and puts my babies at risk. One Unhappy momma here!

Review:
My son is 13 months, very tall little dude. This seat works great for him. no pinching or discomfort...even on the smallest settings. Very well made (sturdy frame, soft/sporty looking material, easy harness)and a reasonable price. I saw it in stores for $50-150.00 higher than I bought it for! If you're familiar with Graco infant seats, than this one will be easy to use. Can be moved from one vehicle to the next with ease(I use the latch system in my Camry hybrid). The recline is just enough for my sons head not to roll forward. Cup holders and storage are nice as well.

The only drawback so far is the reassembly after cleaning. It takes a while the first time (about an hour). This should be easier now that I know how.

Review:
we purchased this car seat from a local retailer. we thought that it would be great to have something that would carry our son all the way through. as it turns out we tried to install the carseat into our Lexus and it did not recline properly. we would have been bringing our baby home sitting straight up. we opted to purchase a car seat and stroller set that will better fit our baby when he arrives. we are going to keep the car seat we purchased already and use that when he is older and will fit better into it. the reviews I've read are mostly good so we feel that this car seat is probably pretty decent for older children plus our car has a lot of safety features and high safety ratings. I'm only giving it three stars because it does not install properly as an infant seat like it says. we tried to make it recline more using the towel and the pool noodle trick to no avail. perhaps if our car were an SUV or minivan instead of a sedan it might have worked but it was far less expensive to buy a different car seat than a different car. I hope this helps people out that are researching and considering this car seat.

just a reminder for you parents out there regardless of which car seat or carrier you are purchasing for your baby you can go to your local fire station and have them inspect the installed car seat or carrier to make sure that it is safe and in the correct position. once our new car seat comes in we will be taking it to our local fire station to have it okayed to bring the baby home in. this is a free service and takes no time at all and better safe than sorry.

Review: So far, this car seat has been everything we could ask for. It's got plenty of room for our little one. The color is pretty neutral so it doesn't clash with the interior of the vehicle. The base is good size and doesn't do any damage to my leather seats. It is big however. You can fit 2 of these in the back seat of a car or small suv. But the middle seat becomes useless. I could fit 3 of these in the back of my 2019 Silverado. If you've got a large back seat, and need the 3rd seat, you're good to go. If you need the 3rd seat and are installing 2 of these in a car or small SUV, IE 2019 Terrain, then you'll want to get something else. The price is good. Styling is good. I've got nothing bad to say about this seat at all. The tightening strap is a little difficult to pull tight at first. Once it's been used a few times though, it gets easier. Also, one of the straps that goes from the bottom of the buckle to under the car seat likes to get twisted. Mostly how I set my child in the seat. If I'm not paying attention, when I tighten it down while twisted, it wont tighten well. You'll want to make sure that all of the belts are straight before you tighten.

Review:
This is our first convertible seat after using a Graco infant seat for the first 1.5 years. I was looking for a breathable material because my child is always hot and sweaty. I liked that this seat had that option and it seems meshy enough that it *might* work.

The biggest reason we chose this one is the strap to tighten it pulls so smoothly and effortlessly. We tried it in the store and were blown away how much easier it was. I got it 3 months ago and I’m loving everything about it. The Graco infant seat was annoying to adjust and I felt I had to pull very hard to get it right enough for my child’s safety, but this is so smooth and easy to pull. This alone has been such a stress reliever when leaving the house.

My second favorite feature is the Clicktight mechanism. I’ve heard how difficult and annoying it is to switch convertible seats between cars, but I’m not even joking that it takes two minutes to move this one. I was surprised that it recommends the seatbelt rather than the latch system. It’s SO much faster and easier. No standing on the seat and tugging a strap to tighten it (y’all know you’ve done it!) or breaking your hands trying to undo the latch hooks buried in the abyss of your seat. You just stretch the seatbelt across and close the seat down to clamp it in. I don’t know how it works but it gets a tight fit every single time with zero wiggle. I watched for sales for a long time (these rarely are discounted if at all) and finally bit the bullet on Cyber Monday. I paid about $220. I have no regrets!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Material: breathable material, meshy
Harness Type: strap to tighten it pulls so smoothly and effortlessly, smooth and easy to pull
Installation Type: Clicktight mechanism, recommends the seatbelt rather than the latch system
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat needs to have breathable material.  
The harness strap needs to tighten smoothly and effortlessly.  
The installation mechanism needs to be easy to use, such as a clicktight design.  
It is acceptable if the seat is recommended for use with the seatbelt rather than the latch system.

Review:
I purchased the updated Britax Boulevard (ClickTight) about a year ago after owning two previous versions of the Britax Boulevard 70 (about 3 years old). Based on the pictures I see on Amazon, my older version is similar to the Britax Boulevard G4 and not the 'new' ClickTight version which was not available 3 years ago. In my opinion, this is a case where newer is not better.

I believe that this new version has a number of serious flaws as I will describe below, the biggest of which is the ClickTight feature. If you try to install the seat tightly (which is a fundamental goal when installing a car seat), you will find that, because of the way the ClickTight feature works, it is possible to lock the seat in so tightly that it cannot easily be uninstalled -- while I understand that is in part by design, it is very difficult to predict how loosely you have to install the seat in order for the tightness to be appropriate. To uninstall the seat, you are forced to turn a small disk using your fingers in a way that you cannot generate sufficent leverage if you install the seat too tightly (which, as I mention, is part of the goal), and I ultimately had to use a vise grip just to uninstall the seat, causing damage to the car seat. Prior to my involvement in installing the seat, my wife was completely unable to remove the seat as she could not turn the ClickTight disc at all. I have installed/uninstalled this seat several times, and the difficulty of unlatching and removing the seat has been an issue nearly every time.

The seat is also unnecessarily difficult to install, particularly in comparison to our prior Boulevard but also compared to other model car seats that we have used. If you are used to having easy-on/off LATCH connectors (that's language from the description of the Boulevard G4, which has such easy to use connectors like most other carseats), forget about it here -- the Boulevard ClickTight has metal anchors which are both difficult to install and difficult to remove, forcing you to put pressure on the latch to hold it open while trying to latch blindly to the LATCH tethers. Depending on your car, this could be a very difficult task.

The ClickTight harness only allows certain degrees of snugness, often resulting in the harness feeling too tight or too loose. I am used to pulling the harness strap tightly enough so that it feels snug but not so tightly that you feel like you're squeezing the air out of your child; with the new ClickTight harness, I find that, depending on how my child is dressed, I am either harnessing too tightly or too loosely, and rarely at the level of snugness and comfort that I can achieve with my other car seats. I am not confident that the seat is sufficiently snug because there are only certain predefined levels of tightness.

Once harnessed in, the release button is buried in a hold between your childs legs. If you don't have particularly long fingers or are wearing gloves, you will likely find it difficult to conveniently push the button such that it releases the harness. Keep in mind that you have to apply pressure to the button in the hole while at the same time pulling the straps forward in order to release them; it's not an impossible task, just made more difficult by Britax's design decision to put the button in a hole. On the plus side, as I've discovered, the hole is a great place to store lost crumbs, cereal, dust, lint, etc. (I'm kidding of course, it's just a terrible design).

I can't speak to issues like length of strap or buckle discomfort as mentioned by other reviewers as the child who sits in this seat is not old enough where these are an issue. Once you get past the ClickTight issue and are able to unlatch the seat, it is just as easy to uninstall as other seats I have used, though it is more difficult to install than any other seat I have used largely due to the type of anchors used. As it's too late for me to return this seat, I've finally made the decision to put the seat in the dumpster, it's just not worth the frustration -- I would not recommend that anyone buy or use this car seat.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: Clicktight, Latch
Harness Type: ClickTight harness
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be easy to install securely using a clicktight or latch system. The harness should be simple to fasten and adjust with a clicktight mechanism.

Review:
This is an ok car seat. I bought it for my 4th child, and I already want to get rid of it. I am sure it keeps the child perfectly safe. It is definitely the worst car seat I have own. Here are the major engineering flaws:

- the seat cushion is cozy, but it has a lot of overlaying flaps, instead of being one piece of fabric. This means there is several obscure places for food to unnoticably collect.
- under the seat there are crevices for food and any spilt drinks to collect. You may think you cleaned the spill, but unless you pull the cover apart and clean under the cover, deep into the crevices, the split drink will saturate the hiding food and make for a perti dish of pure nastiness.
- the spongy material does not dry quickly and is not easily removing for washing.
- when forward facing, you can no longer use the latch system. You are on to the seat belt latch system. For $300, it should be engineered to latch both ways.

Review:
The side wing of the foam headrest is fragile and can break off easily. I sent Britax 2 complaints via their website since my product was still under warranty. Although they claim they would respond within 48 hours, they did not honor that commitment. After 10 days of non-response, I posted a public complaint via their website. The complaint was reviewed by Britax and the response I got from them was that they could not publish my complaint publicly. So, after 12 days of waiting for a response, the only response I got was that they wouldn't post my complaint. I still have not received a response on my original complaint. I'm posting the full correspondence for the public's benefit:

Original Post:
Product + Customer Service FAIL!
I bought the Boulevard in preparation to transition my son into a toddler car seat. We were switching to Britax from a competitor brand, which we used as the infant car seat, because of a friend's recommendation. After a few months of use, the side wing of the foam head rest snapped off in the action of putting my son into the seat. I would have expected this piece to be able to withstand the repetitive motion of moving back and forth. As ANY parent would know, putting a child into a car seat is NOT like an adult settling into his favorite armchair: sometimes the angle is awkward, sometimes the child resists, sometimes the child stands. When the side wing snapped, there wasn't any particular struggle and nothing noticeably harsh and it clearly gave out of repetitive (though ROUTINE) use. I contacted Britax about this July 4th. Given that this was a holiday, I didn't expect an answer and gave them 3 days. On the evening of the 7th, I sent another question/complaint through their website. Since I still have not received a response (now July 12th), not even an auto-reply, I thought this warranted a public post so that future potential customers could be aware. On a side note, though no less important for safety conscious parents, in my question to Britax, I also mentioned that the toddler shoulder belts were unevenly tensioned when I tightened them around my son's shoulder. Even though I would pull the strap to tighten the belt, my son's left shoulder strap would still be loose while his right shoulder strap was tight. There was no obvious snag when I checked the back of the car seat. This issue was present from Day 1 of using the Boulevard. I continued using it because I could set the chest buckle higher to minimize the "give" in the looser shoulder strap.

Britax Response:
Our staff has read your review and values your contribution even though it did not meet all our website guidelines. Thanks for sharing, and we hope to publish next time!

Harness Type: toddler shoulder belts, chest buckle
Material: foam headrest
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

The headrest offers cushioning and support.

I would recommend this car seat but please be sure that it is balanced and tight, if you are concerned with the seat being too loose, take it to your local firehouse so they can properly install the seat. Safe driving to you and yours!

Review: We recently purchased the PP Convertible in Paloma and couldn't be more pleased. I HATED the PP infant car seat (seating angle, canopy, base, etc) and went with the Britax Chaperone (LOVED it) so I was a tad hesitant about purchasing the PP convertible despite the stellar reviews. Our 10 month old is almost too long for the Chaperone so we decided to upgrade him to a "big kid seat". Luckily we were able to compare the Britax seats the PP non-leatherette seat (Crystal Beige, they didn't have the leatherette in store) at a local store and really loved all the features especially the recline angles and general comfort of the seat, but the thought of cleaning the jersey fabric with our little mess-ball was enough to give me a panic attack. The Paloma fabric is amazing! It's really expensive for a car seat, but spend the extra money for the leatherette fabric. It's definitively worth it and will save your sanity! Just a damp cloth and whatever the little man has caked on it comes right off without any fuss. No removing the fabric (even though you can); literally just wipe it down. Also, I have no problem fitting it in a sedan, CUV and full size SUV. It's smaller than the Chaperone in that sense, but still very roomy for the little guy. It's also the most comfortable seat I have ever seen (obviously haven't tested it myself though) and I have researched them ALL! The little man looks so comfy in it and seems happy to be in his new "big kid seat". I also was pleasantly surprised at how much room rear-facing their still is for long legs... Will definitely help keep him rear-facing until closer to 2 than other seats would. Only con besides the expense is the fact there is no canopy, but that is with all the convertibles so not a big deal. You definitely get what you pay for with this seat: functional, beautiful and easy! Install was a breeze! Totally worth every penny!!

My son can get in and out of it himself, just as quick as he can his Harness car seat. We like having these around, just in case.

My only complaint are the function of the red winged things that hold the belt. They only work one way and have to be moved from a slide underneath the seat. Those are a small PIA, but workable. Nothing is perfect. My son doesn't like this seat for longer trips. He really prefers his 5 pt harness seat.

Review:
I purchased two of these car seats for both of our vehicles during the black friday sale ($95). This is the worst purchase ever. They are unbelievable difficult to tighten the chest straps and I have to jump through hoops to get my child strapped in. It takes several minutes and tons of tugging to tighten and it still doesn't pass the pinch test. I've tried all of the hacks and they still do not allow me to get a snug fit on my child. My babysitter has the Graco slim fit and does not have this issue. It's concerning that multiple people report this issue and Graco still keeps this carseat on the market. I did not have this issue with the chicco car seat and I wish I wasn't fooled by the price, 5 star reviews, and for whatever reason this seat passed multiple independent crash tests with higher safety ratings than the Britax I wanted. I discarded the box and cannot return. I would not trust getting in an accident with this car seat or even having to slam the breaks.

Yes, I checked strap alignment and correct height adjusted for my child. This model appears to have this issue and discussed in mutliple reviews and online search hacks. This is a terrible product to keep on the market. I will be trashing these instead of trying to resell. $200 is not worth any child's life.

Review: I too am wondering why the price is so expensive on here, compared to Walmart (where we bought ours).  The only thing I can think of is that this carseat is so high in demand, and sold out at many places, that they are selling it from a company with a really high price.  I would definately wait until the price goes down to get this seat.  That said, this carseat is absolutely the best one yet.  I origally wanted to buy one for my three year old nephew (who I care for) because his seat was getting outdated.  Instead, I ended up buying two of these, one for him and one for his 5 year old sister.  She was already in a plain booster seat, but I decided to buy this so she can be in a harness longer.  Now, she should fit with the harness until she is at least 7, which is a whole lot safer.  She actually doesn't mind being back in a carseat, because this seat is so cool, with it's cup holder and two "secret treasure holders."  I also love the buckle (which I can open with one hand) compared to my nephew's old system.  It is also easier for my neice to buckle the harness then to buckle herself into her booster seat using the car seat belt.  So much faster!  Another bonus, this carseat is also safe for one year olds on up.  I do home daycare and occasionally have different kids using the seats.  This carseat has straps that are the absolute easiest to adjust.  It litterally takes seconds. I origally thought the price of $150 was high (and that was when I was planning on buying just one!), but it truly is the last carseat you will need to buy.  It is a fantasic carseat and soo worth the price.  There are probably more expensive carseats that aren't as nice.  And for the added piece of mind of having them in a harness longer, priceless.

Review:
We really liked the Portabout 5 Evenflo infant carseat we had used with our 1st child but unfortunately we couldn't find that base when we were expecting our 2nd child. So we went with Evenflo Brand again with the Discovery.

I do like how it is rated for a little bit bigger child up to 22lbs / 29" vs the 20lb / 26" limit on the Portabout. Both my boys have been big (9+lbs and one almost 23' long at birth) So the infant carseat won't work for them for too long.

I never had a problem with either handle not staying where it was supposed to.

Discovery is a bit harder to manuver a sleeping baby in and out of the car. The hook on the front of the carseat needs to be tipped forward to hook in, then the back snaps down, so if baby is sleeping they are tipped forward to get hooked in. The portabout didn't have to be tipped as severly forward because there wasn't a hook it needed to hook into. Some claim the Portabout was hard to get in and out, I never experienced this.

The only real complaint I have with the Discovery is the flat piece that holds the 2 straps together tends to slide down. I follow the instructions to slide it up to Baby's armpits height, but even if he's sleeping that piece slides down to about his stomach area, in a short 5 mile car ride. I would say the seat would be greatly improved and rank a 5 star if they just replaced the sliding connector with the plastic clip one they used in the Evenflo Portabout. Wherever I slide that one into position I find it stays put. Personally I found a new base for the Portabout on the web and have ordered it. I'm going to go back to the Portabout carseat. The connector concerns me that if I were in an accident, I am not convinced he would stay in the seat very well. I'll take the reduced size limit and get my 2 year old a booster seat combo and move my youngest into the convertable carseat when he gets too big for the Portabout.

Hope this helps you make a safe decision for your little one.

Seat Type: infant carseat, convertable carseat
Weight Range of Child: up to 22lbs, 20lb limit
Installation Type: hook on the front of the carseat needs to be tipped forward to hook in, then the back snaps down
Harness Type: 2 straps, flat piece that holds the 2 straps together, sliding connector, plastic clip
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

It should support children up to at least 20–22 pounds.

I was hoping that the Traveling Toddler would be great, but I found that it too much torque and stress on the suitcase. To add the weight of my car seat (a Britax) and my 22 pound 1 year old was just too much weight for the handle of the suitcase. It felt awkward and unstable. The physics of it just did not work. So, we put the seat in a bag with wheels and dragged it behind us. The bag was also better for our trip because we fly stand-by and wait and see what seats are left. There was no more window seats available on one of our flights, so we gate checked the seat and I was happy to know that it was protected.

Review:
What do you do when your 3-4 month old keeps trying to sit up in her small infant seat?..... Buy a convertible of course! I researched for a week or so until I decided on this seat. I bought mine at Target because we had a gift card there.

I own an older model (2001) Toyota Camry and it fits perfectly in it (even without LATCH it doesn't budge) without having to compromise the front passenger seat. The seat is HIGHLY padded that I kind of just want to sit in it myself sometimes. Seat belt holders are very convenient when getting Baby in and out (and taking cute pictures without the seat belt!). What's not to love about this seat? My 4 month old (25 inches/16 pounds) fits perfectly in here as well as my 5 year old son (not that he needs a comfy ride since he's stuck in school all day).

I highly recommend this seat to anyone with a small car.

Review:
The good:
✓ Very easy to assemble (I only cracked open the instructions after I had it in place)
✓ Takes only seconds to install thanks to the single-latch system
✓ Comfortable with memory foam like padding
✓ Bench seat Friendly narrow profile
✓ Clean design
✓ Fabrics surfaces are easy to remove (great for cleaning if/when they get soiled)
✓ High safety rating

The meh:
☹ No metal parts on hinge, when putting high-back into place I was a bit concerned about breaking the joints.
☹ While removable, the armrest height isn't adjustable and kids grow fast

Conclusion:
I'm happy to recommend this booster seat. This model compares favorably in safety, features, look and feel to booster seats that cost twice as much from "designer" brands. While I wish they included some metal on the critical parts to improve durability, I doubt I'll be moving it much from one car to another.

---
Edit: Can't find the cup holder?
For those (like me) who don't bother reading the instruction manual when setting up the chair, the cup holder arrives tucked away under the seat.

Review:
This seat works great and is easy to install and remove. However I have two major complaints:

1) It rattles a LOT. If your kiddo is not in it, there is a metallic rattle that will drive you nuts. I broke it down to the styrofoam and still cannot figure out how to stop the rattle. Very frustrating. I think it is the metal frame piece vibrating against something underneath the bottom of the seat. I am going to try to figure out how to take the recline base off to see if I can fix it. Frustrating.

2) The cup holders are worthless. Absolute trash. The first corner you turn the sippy cup will flip right out of it into the seat or worse into the crevice between the seat and the door. My 4 yr old has even learned to just not use them and hold the sippy in her lap.

For the 1st time I tried maxi Cosi mico AP and all I can say is if I ever have any more kids, I'll definitely go back using chicco keyfit 30. Overall Chicco is much higher quality, has stable heavy duty base and is very spacious carseat, (even though I'm not using it for my 2 year old son, but that big boy still fits in it) vs. Maxi cosi is tight in the shoulders for a small child who still needs to stay in rear facing carseat. Quality of the maxi cosi is poor. Wabbly handle, horrible design and quality of the canopy and so on. The only thing I like about maxi cosi vs. chicco is the fabric.

Review:
I bought this so I didn’t have to transfer car seats weekly when I have my 2yo niece and also because I have a small vehicle and hated having a massive car seat taking up room in the back.
The cup holder being optional is so neat, I don’t know that it saves extra room having it slid in but the placement of them is a lot less wide than the previous seat I had. Its not as hard for her to reach her drinks now, I don’t know if this is just a specific issue for my tiny girl, but a definite plus for us.
The seat as a whole looks to be more comfortable for her to be in.
* Installation literally takes MINUTES! I can’t begin to describe how grateful I am for the anchor straps that simply click in place. I loooathe having to fight with the hook kind to get them on/off. These you just have to push against the anchor, listen for the click, and pull to adjust your straps. Then to remove the seat all you have to do is push a button to release them! The straps are also soo much easier to grip in order to tighten. The car seat feels more secure and doesn’t budge as much as others I’ve used. The chest straps don’t seem to loosen and need adjusted as much when taking the seat in and out which is a big plus. The chest clip snaps together differently than I’ve saw before so she’s not able to push in the button and unclip herself like she did with the last seat!
If you’re like me and spend 8 years reading reviews before making the purchase, do yourself a favor and go ahead and buy this!

Review:
The Hiccapop UberBoost is the perfect portable car seat for kids about toddler age and up, to about age 10 or 12, depending on your child's size and weight. It's easy to inflate, deploy, and deflate. The carrying bag makes it perfect for travel. We also now use it every day, as our kids are older and don't need more than a booster.

A few years ago, we spend several months researching portable booster seats for travel, with a lot of confusing reviews and advice. After an initial look through US, UK, and European approved models, we were down to a few brands, using the top car seat review websites.

A look at reviews narrowed the choice to the two that we tried, the Mifold and the Hiccapop. While a little bulkier, the Hiccapop is lighter in weight and was our kids' clear preference in terms of comfort. Hiccapop has a great line of products overall and excellent support as well.

Review: We purchased this car seat while staying with my father in law in Florida on vacation. We have used the chicco key fit for everyday use for both our boys, and this product truly does not compare. It is scarily light weight.  We used this with a 13 pound baby, as well as a 19 pound baby. It truly felt like the plastic carrier could crack, or the handle detach, at any moment. Also, the sun shield is a flimsy joke. The seat is made if light weight plastic and there is NO padding or styrofoam between cover and molded seat.  On the plus side, I still believe this is a Safer choice then renting a carseat on vacation or sending your everyday carseat through checked baggage to be tossed around. Also, it was easy to install. In truth it reminded me of the plastic infant cabbage patch carrier I had as a kid. In closing, I would recommend feeling and seeing this product in person before purchasing as a carseat that will be used with any regularity.

Review: I boought this booster car seat for my 2.5 years old daughter after extensive search and comparison. Overall, I like this product and my daugther too, particularly the cupholder and storages under the armrest. The two areas I would like to see some improvements are the recline design and the headrest. The 3-position recline design is not really a true recline. It doesn't change the angle between lags and back. It is just like one putting a bath towel under the seat. This is my main complaint. As for the headrest, when my daughter sleeps, her head keeps falling down forward, rather than resting on the headrest or the back of the seat. This is probably related to the recline function since there is no way to tilt the angle of the headrest. For me, it would be a perfect product if Graco could resolve the two concerns.

It's important I have the option to simply lift carseat out of car if my older baby is sleeping and I don't want to wake him! I don't plan to always remove it from the car as he gets heavier, but the OPTION is key. We bought the infant stroller carrier by Graco that this clicks into, as well.

Review:
The Cadillac of car seats.
Yes, this car seat is a bit more pricey, but hear me out.

We initially bought this when my son turned a year old. Absolutely loved everything about it he sat comfortably in it, super easy and roomy while he was still rear facing and it’s SO EASY TO CLEAN!!!! You just unzip the cover and it pops right out.. no need to fiddle with annoying straps and trying to remember how things went back together. That had me sold until recently.

We were in a really bad car accident, on the side that my son was on. Someone pulled out in front of us and we hit them. Our car was totaled but my son was perfectly safe and completely unharmed. I will be purchasing this car seat for all the future babies I have and will recommend it to anyone and everyone. Make the purchase, you won’t regret it! I cannot recommend this car seat enough! Remember, you get what you pay for. A $99 car seat sounds great, but I doubt it would have held up as good as this one did in our accident. I didn’t hesitate to purchase another one after the accident to replace the old one... seriously the best of the best right here!!

Review:
I read and read reviews before purchasing this car seat. I read that people loved it and those that didn't had issues with it that didn't affect me so I decided to save about $100 and ordered this seat. I was excited but the more I've had the seat, the less thrilled I have been with it. Here are my likes/dislikes.

Likes:
It has a handy dandy cup holder.
Has a harness and converts to a booster "this will be the last seat my son may need!"
Did I mention the cup holder? yeah? ok...

Dislikes:
The latch system.
Ignorance is bliss... If you have only ever used this brand perhaps this isn't an issue for you. However- I think every parent should know that there are MUCH MUCH better latching systems out there. These little metal clips are junk and the fact that in order to get the latching systems's belt pulled tightly I have to try to thread it through the seats back and try to pull the strap to the side (the direction of "out" of the car) all while kneeling in the seat to ensure its in snug is a pain and usually requires the help of another person. Pretty annoying for a do it yourself-er or someone that travels solo with the kids and doesn't enjoy doing this in an airport parking lot... or at all for that matter. We don't move the seats all that often (some parents transfer seats often- this seat would be a pain if you planned to use latches)but enough to be completely annoying and worry some. I'm a stickler for having my seats in snug with little to NO wobble.

Seat Parts-
So- kids are dirty. This seat was made to be able to wash the pads/cover Yay (oops that should be a plus) BUT- after removing the seat pads and pieces a foam piece on the headrest that states DO NOT REMOVE fell right off. (its not attached- just sort of hangs there). Ok, no big deal- pop it back on. Well- not a big deal until your child comes by and the piece snaps in half (I swear he barely touched it). My first thought... ok maybe 2nd. First thought was gee I'm pissed. Then- okay- quick- give a call and order a new one! Not open and before and after I tried calling I tried their web page. Followed the directions in entering the model and serial number and its not working. Must be an issue because after the first of many tires there was a pop up to call the 800 number.

so- third negative- difficult to get to the parts ordering section of the web page with this seat's model number. (are those Ohs or zeros? hmm neither work! What about a space here, one there? nope, nope nope.

the crotch buckle-
yup, I read about this in other reviews. I had put my kiddo in the seat in the store and figured- eh, I can adjust it and it will be fine! Wrong-O! They gave approximately 4cm of wiggle room in the belt... perhaps that is one of the ways they save costs on the seat??

***This part isn't Graco's fault but if you're a parent and you don't realize this- you need to b/c I've seen/talked to people who don't know better and it freaks me out. Yes- this seat has a harness NO your 9 month old who can sit up or who is 20lb already should NOT use this seat yet! Should STILL BE IN REAR FACING. I've even heard/read people saying something about 6 mo olds. YIKES. NO!
And- the "recline" handle should read TILT- if your child is both old enough and big enough to use the forward facing seat they do not need to be reclined (adults aren't even supposed to ride reclined in the car) this tilting is to adjust the seat to your car peeps.

In reading many many many of the reviews- I read some Britax haters. One commented that people that have Britax just like to throw around the name... First I was like really? Hmm, maybe so. Maybe I too am being a Britax snob. Maybe I don't need to spend the extra money....and Now- I tell them why Britax (or another better brand)... Because the Britax seats FAR surpass the quality and user friendliness of the Graco seats. Those that have used the bucking latch system that has release buttons to remove the seat and ***a strap on EITHER side of the seat to tighten it in***. This is important- because getting your seat in snug and tight is the whole point of a car seat. To keep your babies stable should anything happen.
Other brands have the same button release latches that self tighten now!!! YOu just latch, kneel/sit in the seat and push back and no tugging belts! yay!
SO- when looking at a seat- study the latch system, the clips across the chest- many of these things are better quality in the pricier seats. Some say- oh you're just paying for better fabric in those seats. Its not just the fabric.
You get what you pay for. I re-learned that lesson with this seat :(

Happy shopping!
(go get something else)

Review: My granddaughter who is seven has no problem hopping in and buckling herself up. The red clips on the side are easy for her to manage. I drive a Chevy Spark (yes it is very small) and this is the only booster that fits with enough room for the seatbelt receptacle on the seat to be exposed, which is why she can buckle it herself. The previous one I had was a Graco, and we had to move the booster a little bit 'sideways' to expose that seatbelt clip. It was still too tight a fit for her to do it herself, plus she wasn't completely facing forward. If you've seen the Sparks backseats they are slightly 'bucket seats'. Just slightly, but if a booster doesn't fit right and has to moved towards the door more to clip the seatbelt, then not only is it not completely straight forward, the seat actually tips a tiny bit inward due to the not level car's seat. Can't tell you how happy I was to find this BubbleBum!

Review: I had to purchase another booster seat as my truck was hit and sadly totaled, but was told what played an important roll to my son's car seat staying put and saving his life and not being thrown out the door as his door was t-boned and opened was the LATCH system. And this seat has it. I could have been a spokes person and when I do see my friends who has those flimsy car seats, say they are not safe, and accidents will happen and sadly those seats will not stay put, and explain the latch system and that it hooks directly to the metal bars under the back seat. I had the Graco 3 in 1 from when he was born, and I had it so tight I use to say if I ever flipped my truck, I would know my son was not going anywhere, and sadly we did not flip all the way over, but when the officers and the ambulance stated that car seat kept him from being thrown about, I looked everywhere for just a booster with the Latch system.

Review: I would highly recommend a travel cart in general--it made it so much easier for us to get through the airport, especially when all our two-year old wanted to do was escape and "run around!"  I had a hard time deciding whether to order this cart or the Gogo Babyz cart, but ultimately decided on this one since some of the Gogo Babyz reviews indicated problems with the wheels coming off in the newer model.  I have not tried the other brand to be able to compare, but I can say that we had NO issues with the Britax cart not being stable, tipping over, or otherwise.  We asked to have the car seat, still attached to the cart, hand-checked when going through security, which was not a problem at any airport we went to.  We did go ahead and detach the car seat from the cart before boarding the plane, as we have a wide Britax marathon car seat and I do not think it would have fit down the aisle if we had rolled it on.  My husband found it easiest to lift the car seat completely over his head to get it to our seat.  The cart folded up and fit under the seat in front of our toddler.  We left her in her "special stroller" on the buses and trains at the airports.  My husband and I agree that this product was a definitely lifesaver for our trip, and we would highly recommend it.

Review: This car seat is great, specifically because the functions are easy to use and it's actually lightweight. The colors are gender neutral, so that's a plus. There's a lot of cushioning, making the seat comfortable for the child. There is a latch in the front that adjusts the bottom of the seat, changing it from infant and toddler position. The latch is conveniently located in the front so you don't have to lift the entire seat to do it. Also, the head rest slides up a few levels, by pulling it up to the desired level- there is no removing and having to take anything off to adjust things. My favorite part is the straps, they can be adjusted to different level by pulling them up or down and making sure they snap at that level. That is so much better than removing the car seat and taking the straps out and re-adjusting them. You don't even have to take the child out of the seat to do this. Overall, it is a great car seat.

Review: We purchased a Graco Cargo seat for my almost 4 year old son and hated it from the first moment - it never seemed secure in our Town and Country van and it was a pain in the butt to adjust the harness.  After reading lots of favorable reviews, we decided to go for the Nautilus and we're so glad we did.  It feels very secure in my van (we used the LATCH) and the harness is very easy to adjust.  The cup holder is actually useful - many other seats have it placed some place where my son couldn't even reach it.  There's plenty of padding around the head that allows for some comfort if our son falls asleep and there have been no complaints whatsoever of "pinching."  I LOVE the fact that the harness weight limit is so high and that it turns into a regular booster for down the road - we can feel good about this purchase because we will get years of use out of it. I will highly recommend it to my friends.

Review: I fit three of these across in the back of my 2017 Honda Civic Si. This particular one (the third) is rearfacing. My only complaint is that it has a longer distance front to back when rear-facing than others I’ve used. The passenger seat has to be pushed as far forward as the car will allow, so anyone taller than 5’6” would struggle to sit in the front seat. Nevertheless, I think these seats are by far the best car seats I’ve owned because they are sleek, simple, and can fit 3 across with ease. I have had Britax and Clek car seats as well, but I wouldn’t buy them again knowing how versatile Diono is. Just FYI, Clek says they can fit 3 across, and they can in most places (like our Honda Pilot), but they will not fit 3 across in a 2017 Honda Civic. Gotta have the Diono for that.

Review:
When we needed a second car seat for my husband's new car, this is the one we ended up getting (for a 2 yr old who is 36 inches tall and 32 lbs). Currently we have the Orbit toddler seat in my car (SUV) and once our daughter tried the Britax, it was apparent that it fit her much better than the Orbit has. It's roomier, it fit easily in the back seat of a MINI Cooper Countryman, it's lighter and the install was much easier. I wish we had tried it earlier and finally just broke down and ordered a second one to replace the Orbit seat.

We bought a separate cover for the first one and getting it on was easy and fast. Our daughter loves the cup holders which is a small thing but seems to make her very happy. Since we routinely travel 90 min to see family, it's nice she can have her water back there or a place to store some toys.

I guess my best detail is that if your child is on the taller and larger side, this is a great car seat (with plenty of room to grow and adjust) for a toddler! The Orbit system has always been a bit too small for us (infant seat and toddler seat especially in the shoulder area). Our child just loves it!

Review:
I really like this stroller. I LOVE that my carseat (the Safety 1st OnBoard 35) clicks right into it without any problems and that it's so lightweight and easy to set up. However, I wish that 1) it was easier to turn; it is almost impossible to maneuver one-handed and sometimes it has problems not wanting to turn on linoleum. It feels like it's dragging sideways rather than having the wheels actually turn. 2) the underneath storage was a little more accessible; it's quite a large storage space, but in order to get my diaper bag in there I have to pop the carseat all the way out. The opening between the carseat and the top of the storage compartment is fairly narrow. 3) it was easier to tell if the carseat was all the way in; sometimes we'll put it in and it'll seem to be all the way in, but a little later we hear a click telling us that NOW it's all the way in, whereas before it wasn't. 4 my husband) it had better shock absorbency. I understand it's not a jogging stroller, but you can definitely tell when you're going over a crack in the sidewalk. However, my baby seems to enjoy the off-roading type feeling ;)

Also, the two parts that are red in the picture (the side clip and the button on the handlebar) are actually gray on my stroller.

Aside from these minor complaints, I absolutely LOVE this stroller. I am so glad I bought it and I would definitely recommend it! It is super convenient and doesn't take up much room in the car at all.

Review:
Many reviewers have commented here that the crotch strap is incredibly short. I spent some time agonizing before I finally ordered, since I did not want to have to return it. But it turns out, the crotch strap is plenty long. I even bought a second one for my other child. Here's what you need to do.

1. Once your child is too large for the smallest setting on the 5 point harness, follow the instructions to REMOVE THE BODY SUPPORT. This is the thing that looks like extra padding in what would be the lumbar region if you could somehow squeeze an adult into the seat. In my copy of the manual it is shown on page 6 under "Features". If you fail to REMOVE THE BODY SUPPORT, yes, indeed, the crotch strap appears to be ridiculously short. So, in conclusion, REMOVE THE BODY SUPPORT per the instructions.

2. Also, as many have commented, move the crotch strap to the second slot. Make sure you are using the second slot in the hard plastic base, not just the second slot in the fabric insert.

3.... Read more

Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The harness type is acceptable.

Review:
Overall love the car seat. Pretty easy to install and use. I love that it has a spot to hold the straps out of the way while you are getting your child in the seat. I have not had to wash it yet so I will update once I have. My one complaint: it's hard to tighten the harness straps. I found that once I have my little guy strapped in if I first tighten the straps from the back of the seat (we are still rear facing) it becomes much easier to tighten. Grab right above the metal piece that is holding the straps on the back of the seat and then pull down, this pulls most of the slack and you are able to tighten the harness, then make your adjustments to the chest clip and shoulder pads etc. and then a final pull to tighten. This has made the process much easier to get the right fit without feeling like you need to be He-man to do it.
I have seen a lot of complaints about the cup holders, they are square in shape and most cups do not fit. They work well for holding small toys though and it hasn't really bothered me. However, I was able to find a water bottle to fit! The Disney store is selling square shaped water bottles right now! It was about $10 bucks and fits perfectly!

Review:
I just installed this for the first time in our van. Our baby is due in a few weeks and I wanted it ready to go. The base installs SO easily with latch. You just have to pull a strap, and it gets tight enough with no problem. Every other car seat I have had has been hard to tighten, and I've used quite a few as this is for our 5th child. I didn't have to put a rolled up towel under this seat to get it to the right angle, and that is awesome! I LOVE the level on the base, it makes it easy to see that it's installed properly.

The seat isn't too heavy and we will be able to use it for quite a while. Our daughter will outgrow the maximum height long before the weight. It seems really well cushioned and cozy for a baby, and it looks like it will fit her well.

I will try to remember to update this after baby arrives and we actually use it for a while, but I am VERY happy with it so far!

Review:
Extremely disappointed and will probably NEVER own Britax again! I am a twin mom that immediately purchased B-Safe carriers for my twins, the double B-Agile stroller, then when they turned 11 months old I purchased them both Pavilion 70-G3 convertible cowmooflage print car seats. I loved most everything about them until yesterday.
We went on a road trip over the weekend and one of my girls got a little car sick. We had cleaned it all up but I wanted to wash the entire cover when we returned home to ensure it was clean. When we removed the cover we found that the head restraint 'wings' were severely cracked, like nearly torn off. So we checked the other car seat immediately and found that both sides were completely broke off. This really stressed me out knowing my kids were just on a car trip in these seats and the totted safety features are completely broken.
I started calling Britax this morning and their phone number was temporarily unavailable. I finally got through this afternoon and was told my seats are outside of the 1 year warranty but that I could buy new wing pieces. I told her that the seats are minimally used, my toddlers do not fight getting into them and we have never had an accident. She informed me that they are made of the same foam that is in your cars bumper and are made to break. I said but this is less than normal wear causing them to break, not an accident. She told me the car seat was fine without them but that I would have to pay to replace them.
So if you are looking to buy a car seat and reviewing the extra safety features that make Britax sound like they are worth all that extra $$$$, think again. Those features are meant to break and may have never been keeping my children any more safe than the Chicco or Graco's. What a bunch of misleading marketing or a really great way to ensure they continue to suck money out of you from the constant purchase of replacement parts!
My children do not go in the car daily and sometimes only once per week. We live in the country and prefer to play and roam at home. So this happened in 2 years of our use, imagine how quickly it can happen if you use them daily and have a child that fights getting in the car how quickly it could be happening to others.
Attribute_Related_Content: Material: cover, head restraint 'wings' severely cracked, broken, made of foam
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The cover and head restraint wings should not crack or break easily. The materials used should be durable and not degrade into foam that can crack.

Review:
I purchased two of these from Albee Baby and we love them! First off Albee Baby has very fast shipping!

I have a two year old son and he needed a few more car seats because I was tired of installing my Britax marathon in different cars every few days. I bought two gracos so my husband and I each have one in our cars and that way the marathon can stay in grandma's car because it so easy to buckle him properly for her hands.

I like everything about these seats! They installed with latch super easy and the install is so tight, it's as if it was built into my cars.

I love the fit. My son fits so comfortable in these seats and with the recline feature, plus the natural recline of my back seats it makes naps comfortable for him.

Right now he is on the lowest setting and middle crotch buckle slot. I like that there are 3 crotch slots it will make extended harnessing longer easier as he grows.

I also love the 10 year expiration(from the date of manufacture). That truly means this seat will last him until he no longer needs a seat, so now I Will just have to replace the britax marathon when he outgrows it.

I do love the no rethread harness feature as well, it makes it so much easier not having to take the seat out(which is what I love about my britax.

I don't know what some reviews are talking about when they say they can't get the straps tight enough and that it's hard to adjust the straps. On both of our seats it's super easy. Actually it easier to adjust these straps then on my britax.

My son loves his new seats!

I would recommend these and I love our new seats! I'm glad I opted for two of these instead of the britax frontier.

Review:
The seat is described to be usable either with the harness system or as a booster seat (without harness). For the booster usage, you have to remove the harness. This turns out to be nearly impossible: one has to reach a “splitter plate” inside the seat construction, which cannot be seen, but only be reached by one hand, and one has to wiggle two straps out of this metal plate with one hand in the blind.
Even if one would succeed in this nearly impossible task, obviously one will never be able to put the harness harness back in. So the claim of dual use as harness or booster seat is false; or if the harness is removed with great difficulty, it is for good.
For use only with harness it seems OK (seems safe and comfortable), but I wonder who engineered the dual use feature.

Review: I really wanted to love this seat. It is super easy to install (both seatbelt and latch), has amazing padding, and the adjustable head rest/harness height and recline features are all very good reasons to love this seat. Now the bad, and it's a biggie...the harness is extremely difficult to tighten (moving the pads down helps a little, but it is still difficult). And it wasn't just me - my husband had to use all his force and sometimes it was still too loose. This is a huge safety concern. Comfort, style, and convenient features are not enough for me to overlook safety. I would much rather purchase a budget seat that's a pain to install (as long as it installs safely), with less padding, and fewer features as long as the harness can be tightened as much as it should.

Review:
My son has been in this seat since he was 7 months old. He is now 27 months, 34 lbs, and 38" tall. He has just outgrown the rearfacing limit by height.
To my huge surprize, he only has 2 inches of growth left forward facing as well, even though the seat is supposed to accomodate children upto 49" tall. The headrest is on its last setting and will not go any higher. The seatbelts are supposed to be at or above shoulder level while forward facing, and now he has only 2 inches of that space left. And he is not "all torso" - he doesn't have an elongated body. I am at a loss. I was really hoping this seat would last a bit, since I do love it.

Other than this sudden discovery, I love the seat. Supercomfy for the kid, easy to install with a latch rearfacing or forward facing with latch (I didn't try car belts). Everything I ever wanted, except for - doesn't last as long as I needed it to.

Review: My experience with this car seat was life changing! My newborn was snuggled in for the long trip we had on an incredibly cold and rainy day. We hydroplaned and slammed into a concrete barrier, almost rolled and slammed into the barrier again before we came to our final resting spot, (middle of the highway). We walked away without any injury and the car seat did exactly what it was designed to.  Every single airbag went off in my car and the car seat stayed in place. We had a Graco booster and I decided everyone gets Peg Perego after that experience.  I immediate purchased the exact seat again but in a different color and a booster (HBB 120). DO NOT GO CHEAP on something that may save your child’s life. This seat is well worth the money and would never recommend anything but Peg Perego.

Review:
We bought this convertible car seat because our kids were getting too big for their older Graco car seats ( which by the way were really good).

- Very easy to fix and remove.
- Well padded; hence, very soft to touch.
- No sweat stains yet; maybe it's because I don't see them sweating much in it.
- Lightweight.
- Straps are comfortable and easy to click in and unstrap for adults but not for babies.
So these are all the plus.

The one con I found was that when my babies fall asleep in this rear facing positioned car seat, their head/neck seems very uncomfortable. They are not able to lean back while sleeping, and I hate it when I see their head dropping to their chest once they are asleep. If this car seat could be positioned such that it provides a comfortable sleeping position for little babies, that would be perfect.
