Review:
I researched convertable carseats FOREVER before deciding on one. I went back and forth between this seat and the Recaro Pro-Ride. I actually bought the Recaro Pro-Ride first. When installed forward facing, it is a tank. You child will be protected. My daughter, though, is not ready to ride forward-facing yet. So, I needed this to rear-face for a bit. I could not get the Recaro to safely install in a rear-facing position in my Volvo XC90. (See my review of the Recardo Pro-Ride for more info.) I ended up returning the Recaro and getting the Britax Marathon 70-G3. This seat installed wonderfully in my car in the REAR facing position. No noodle was needed. It has a strap for the rear facing position that lets you connect the top of the seat to the floor of the car, which prevents tipping, which I really like. It is nice and comfy and soft for the baby. It has these plastic covers on the straps, that make it hard to get the straps tight if your baby is tiny, but you can get it to work. I will say, though, that the Britax head proection is not as good as the Recaro. Plus, the Recaro is deeper - your baby sits down in it more, so they are more protected from side impact.

Bottom line for me: This is a great seat for REAR facing. But, I think when I am ready to put my baby in a FORWARD facing postiion, I am going to spend the money and get the Recaro.

Review:
I love this car seat! We're getting into a point where the infant seat is too small for our toddler. I originally ordered another Graco *forward* facing car seat (Tranzitions 3-in-1), but wanted to keep him rear facing for as long as possible. This works well as a rear-facing seat with the recline feature allowing room for his legs to stretch out and up a bit. I do notice some squeaking/rubbing on the back of the front driver's/passenger seats, but I'm 6'2", so my seat is all the way back and probably isn't an issue for *most* drivers. I added a car-seat seat protector so his shoes/feet won't mark up the seat back, and there aren't any issues with this on the seat protector.

It's really quick and easy to install with the seatbelt, but I've so far struggled to get the LATCH anchors free from the base. When I take it out of my car and install it in my girlfriend's car again, I'll spend some more time figuring that out and will update if there were any issues.

Graco is a trusted child safety brand, so I'm trusting the brand that it's safe and hope that I never need to test it first hand.

Review:
Why we love it:
- SAFETY: 5-point harness keeps our 3-year-old more securely in the seat for longer (plan to use until 5 years old)
- LONGEVITY: converts to seatbelt booster for use up to 110 lbs/57 inches
- COMFORT: lots of padding, great for longer car rides
- easy to buckle, doesn't tangle
- great design with lots of detail stitching
- attached to latch system, so it doesn't slide around and is easy for child to climb into
- affordable at under 70 dollars

After many hours of research online, comparing car seats in stores and ordering two car seats as "finalists" from Amazon, we have chosen this one for a number of reasons.

The main consideration for us was keeping our 3-year-old in a 5-point harness seat for as long as possible, but not wanting to purchase a new seat in two years when she moves up to a seatbelt booster. We had to purchase a new seat for her now, because our second child is moving up into her old seat. Technically, our child meets the minimum requirements for a seatbelt booster now, but after reading a few discussion on this, it seems that with every seat "upgrade" (changing to forward-facing, then changing to seatbelt booster) you loose a layer of safety. In fact, even in our car manual it states that due to a child's anatomy, they recommend a 5-point harness until 5 years old (their skeleton isn't mature enough to "properly" handle a car accident if they are using a seatbelt booster this young).

While safety was the biggest selling point for us to choose a convertible 5-point harness/seatbelt car seat, there are a few features that made this car seat stand out within this category. It is very nicely padded and the angle in the car is nice (not too steep or too upright), which makes for a comfortable ride. It's very easy to buckle, tighten, unbuckle, loosen and the straps don't tangle easily. This seat attaches to the latch system of the car, so it doesn't slide around when my 3-year-old climbs in the seat herself (this will be useful when we convert to the seatbelt function as well). As for any carseat that attaches via the latch system, you should check your car specs to see what the weight limit is for using a latch seat.

I also love the colors — sleek and neutral but with a bit of custom stitching and hints of red that give some nice detail. My child loves the cup holders (I never knew she cared, but it's the first thing she noticed...) — they have an elastic band in the front which holds in the cup.

The other seat we had ordered, but ended up returning is the "Evenflo Chase LX Harnessed Booster, Jameson" ([[ASIN:B016UJHJ8K Evenflo Chase LX Harnessed Booster, Jameson]]). The two models are very similar, the main difference was the amount of padding — the Maestro is just so much more comfortable, while with the Chase seat you could feel the hard plastic through the thinner padding.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Convertible, Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: up to 110 lbs/57 inches, until 5 years old
Installation Type: latch system
Harness Type: 5-point harness, seatbelt booster
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should accommodate children up to 110 pounds and 57 inches tall, suitable for use until about 5 years old. It should be a convertible seat that can be used in both rear-facing and forward-facing positions. Installation should be possible using the vehicle's LATCH system. The seat should feature a 5-point harness for secure restraint and should also function as a seatbelt booster when the child is older.

Review:
We bought this for my son when he was 6 months old because the infant carrier we had plus the chunky monkey was just too heavy. He's now just over 3 years old (36lbs & 36in) and still fits in it, rear-facing, perfectly! He honestly never complains about it being uncomfortable, so it must fit him well. It's pretty easy to install and wash (we've gotten lots of practice over the past 2.5 years), and always feels really sturdy when installed, not wiggly at all. We take pretty long trips regularly and have even taken this along on a plane, no complaints from anyone!
The only con is that we got the tan and black version, and after 2.5 years there are some visible stains on the seat that I can't get out, but that's not a deal breaker for us. I wish it was a darker color or a bit more stain resistant.
We drive a Toyota Venza and have the seat installed behind the passenger. The seat does have to be forward a bit, but I (5'6") still fit very comfortably, even for long trips. It's a little bit of a tighter fit for my husband (6'1"), but it works!

Bottom line - EXCELLENT DEAL. Hits every quality I look for in a good purchase.

Review:
We really liked this seat, at first. However, after some time using it we began experiencing a lot of difficulty tightening/securing our child into the seat. It would take so much strength to tighten it that we were afraid we were going to hurt our child, so we contacted the manufacturer who was fantastic and without hesitation, offered to replace the seat. Fast forward to now (about a year later with the new seat) and we've started having the issue again, only this time it seems much worse. We've removed the seat from our vehicle and brought inside and inspected it and found nothing wrong with it. As a trial, we put our daughter in the seat in the house and attempted to tighten and still, ot takes so much force to secure our child in the seat. We have noticed on the back of the seat the metal piece that holds the straps seems to be catching on some ridges on the underside of the seat. We have contacted the company again and are waiting to hear back.
Personally, we do NOT recommend this seat.

Update:
We've reached out to the company again in reguards to the issue we were having. They have offered us a replacement unit of an upgraded version of the seat which is the Grow n Go EX Air 3 in 1. Once we receive and us it for a bit I'll give an honest review of that seat.
To those saying that the customer service for Safety First is awful, I have to say they have been wonderful each time that I've contacted them.

Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat should be easy to secure the child into without requiring excessive strength. The harness tightening mechanism should operate smoothly without catching on any parts of the seat.

Cons: it’s so wide compared to our Even-Flo Titans that it doesn’t fit next to her sib in our car like they prefer; they have to be on opposite sides. The built-in cup holders don’t help with that.

It’s a hard choice for travelers on a budget: take one that’s easy to fit anywhere and super light to tote around, or one that’s super easy to move between Ubers.

Review:
Fits wonderful in our 2004 GMC Yukon Denali XL, and 2003 Dodge Ram 2300 Quad Cab.

We already had first generation Boulevards, which we loved (bought in May 2006). My sister recommended the Frontier 85, which she had bought. After reviewing everything I could get my hands on, we purchased 2 of the Frontier 85's (Cowmooflage and Pink Sky). Our daughter (4 years old, 42.5" and 40lbs) loves the color's and I find the fabric very nice, not too keen on the gray on the bottom of the Pink Sky though, the feel of the fabric isn't nice. At first they looked confusing to install, after reading the instructions twice, I had it in the Yukon in under 20 minutes, with my 4 year old's "help" and with the LATCH and tether. Car seat back is nice and tight to the truck seat, tether is nice and tight, that car seat is not going anywhere. Oh, and our Yukon has the captain's chairs NOT the bench.

The car seats were shipped separately and arrived 4 days apart, so this morning we moved the one in the Yukon to the Ram and put the new one in the Yukon. PIECE OF CAKE for the Ram, we can't use the tether due to the rear seat back not moving forward, but once the LATCH was tightened, that seat doesn't move an inch, and there is no gap between the bottom of the seat and the back of the trucks' seat. I installed the new seat in the Yukon next. Total time for both trucks 12 minutes.

I was hesitant on the single pull LATCH tightening, but I LOVE IT. I found it so much easier to get the seat tight, because you can't run out of strap to tighten, which was the problem I had with the Boulevard in the Yukon, I had it as tight as it would go, but is still had a little give. The new LATCH is completely locked down, and once you feed the tightening strap through the slip, you get the angle you were always trying to get on the dual strap models, and it just locks the seat in.

We found that even though this seat is bigger in size then the Boulevard, it fits better in the RAM. The back of the car seat doesn't rest against the back window like the Boulevard, there is actually a 2-3 inch clearance.

Our daughter loves the seats, they give her plenty of space, she loves the cup holders. We love the extra padding Britax put on these seat, the lighter weight, the 5 point harness up to 85lbs was a huge selling point for us, and all the safety features and standards that Britax is known for. We are looking forward to a long and happy relationship with our new Frontier 85's.

Seat Type: Forward Facing
Weight Range of Child: up to 85lbs
Installation Type: LATCH and tether
Harness Type: 5 point harness
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

The car seat should allow installation using LATCH and a tether.

Review:
Me: father of two, one rear-facing and one front-facing.

Pros:
* It is truly narrow, only slightly wider than a roll of paper towel
* The hip flaps cleverly expand to accommodate bigger kids and the seat base folds-up on mechanical hinge for travelling (handy for airport scanners, I suspect).
* It’s also built like a tank, the all-steel construction adds peace-of-mind. Even the head side cushions are super sturdy.

Cons:
* This thing weighs a ton. But as heavy as it is, it doesn’t even have any handles, so it feels even heavier. Despite the folding base, I would never take this on a plane on account of how heavy and awkward it is.
* Also, despite the fancy folding seats, this seat doesn’t even recline! Instead, it comes with a separate attachment (another thing to carry for travelling…) for rear-facing installation that just sort of props it up on one side, which is kind of like shoving a bunch of books underneath to tilt it. This is truly stupid for a $330 car seat. You can acquire their foam pad to shim the seat to different angles, but this doesn’t seem very tasteful to me and the pads are not even included in the box. I suppose anything could be as small as you want it to be, if it was infinitely disassembled into "separate" parts...
* Lastly, this seat leans sideways because of its slimness. I tend to position car seats nearer to the doors to widen the middle seat (the whole point of a slim seat is to salvage the middle seat, after all) and, while other wider child seats would just bridge over minor bumps in the car’s seat cushions, this seat’s narrowness makes it lean into those bumps, making it hard straighten. I suppose some shims would be helpful in this case to level the seat.

If Diono is reading, here are my recommendations for the future:
* Handles or hand-slots for carrying
* If you have room for a folding base, you should find room for an articulating reclining mechanism. Otherwise, if both won’t fit, replace the folding base with a recline mech.
* If you still must keep the prop-up legs, make it collapsible under the seat instead being a separate attachment.
* Consider some kind of a lateral stabilizer like turn-out feet or a tilt-table base. Or in this case, I suppose some shims might be okay, but just include them in the box please!
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: rear-facing, front-facing
Weight Range of Child: bigger kids
Installation Type: rear-facing installation
Material: all-steel construction
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The seat accommodates bigger kids.

Horrible design change. Otherwise a good seat but why did they change it for the worse? In the market for another seat and will now avoid buying this annoying seat altogether now.

Also noted that they finally test or claim they test their side impacts. Does not state the entire seat, just the side impact portion of it. I know Britax test the entire seat itself, something to consider, but at least they are headed in the right direction.

Review:
I ended up keeping it, but really not so happy with it. The two main problems are:
1. The straps are so close to each other they are cutting into my kids neck. I had to find very thin, small and soft padding to cover the upper part of the straps and now it is OK, but really a bad design.
2. The seat is in a very strait, so when he falls asleep he is not in a very good position and his head falls forward.
Also the seat is very low, so he cant see much out of the window.
We are still using it with the harness, So at least the strap thing will be fine once we change into a booster.
It does attach nicely to the car with the LATCH system, and seems to be sturdy.
Bottem line is that it is a good price, but does need some improvements.

Review: We now own 4 of these. 2 in my truck and 2 in my wife's car. They are top notch. I would not go with anything else personally. The only thing I don't like is when they are rear facing they seem a tad jiggly. They are locked in and not going anywhere, but I just wish you could get them a little more solid. You could if you had an anchor on the floor of your vehicle. Also a word of caution. The liners are washable but I strongly recommend NOT putting them in the dryer. We put the first one in the dryer and some of the seams busted open. I have always air dried the ones in my truck and have had no problems.

Review:
I bought this car seat when my son was 3 months old. He has used from rear facing infant seat to the day we totaled our small car. I 100% believe that this car seat helped save my sons life. As a matter of fact, he didn’t even wake up from his nap when the accident happened. Highway patrol had to wake him to make sure he was ok. Thank God for an awesome safe seat for my little guy. This is my 2nd Diono and I will always stick with this brand.
The seat is heavy as it boasts a steel frame, but worth the trouble of moving for all its safety features. The high weight capacity of rear facing is amazing and my son will stay rear facing until he reaches the height/weight restriction for the seat.

Review: We looked at tons of baby seats when our son outgrew his infant seat. I wanted something that would still fit as he got bigger. It has the added bonus of being airline certified, so if we ever need to fly somewhere I know that he will be buckled up safely. My husband says that it's a dream to install and we can switch it easily to grandpa's car. I also like the peace of mind knowing that it has a high safety rating. It was very expensive, but I believe that it's worth it and it is good up to 100lbs, so I plan to use it for several years.

Review:
We have a Graco Turbo Booster as a secondary seat for my 5.5-year-old. We needed a second high-back booster for a short-term transport of one of his friends and since this was cheaper than the Graco and pretty well-reviewed, I bought it. However, were this a long-term-use purchase, I would have sent it back and spent the extra $10-$15 on the Graco, no question whatsoever. I do like the cupholders on the Evenflo, but the padding is inferior to the Graco and the Evenflo would be difficult for napping - the Graco has an extra layer of padding at the head, which is nice for my son, who still zonks out in the car pretty frequently. The Graco also has better padding overall. The Evenflo IS slightly more narrow than the Graco, if space is at a premium, but I would never pick this seat over the Graco for significant use.

As a side note, as many people have pointed out in these reviews, these seats are for kids who are at least 4 years old, and this actually printed on the instruction manual for this seat, even though it's not prominent in the Amazon description. Skeletal maturity is important, not just hitting the height/weight standards.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: high-back booster
Weight Range of Child: at least 4 years old
Material: padding is inferior, extra layer of padding at the head, better padding overall
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The child car seat provides adequate comfort and support for children at least four years old. The padding is acceptable even if it is not the highest quality. Additional head padding is desirable for enhanced comfort. Overall, better padding is a valued feature.

Review: Seat works great.  Especially like the "quick release" LATCH connectors.  Our last seat just had the clips and it would take 10-15 minutes per clip to get them disconnected when we needed to move the seat.  These its just the push of a button just like a seat belt to get the connector loose (they are always out of reach of the child as well).  The shoulder height adjustment is good too.  You just twist a knob to slide the shoulder straps and side impact protection up and down to fit your kid.  The latch to loosen the straps is much better than our last seat as well.  Although, I saw a better designed one when we were looking that had a side mounted knob to loosen or tighten the straps.  The design on this seat is more of the conventional type with a pull strap in between the kids legs and a loosening latch just below the seat covers, but its operation is far better than average for the seats we tried out.  The only things that are kind of a bother are the weight of the seat and the lack of a good level indicator.  It's by far not the heaviest seat we saw, but it is still a bit heavy to move from vehicle to vehicle.  Also, the seat's only leveling indicator is a line on the side of the seat you are somehow supposed to step back and make sure it is parallel to the ground.  Our last seat had an actual level riveted to the side of the seat frame that was much easier and "dummy proof" on leveling the seat.  For something that all the manuals and experts stress as so important, you'd think they could put a better device on it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Forward Facing
Installation Type: LATCH
Harness Type: shoulder straps, pull strap
Material: seat covers
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat should be forward facing.  
The car seat should be easy to install using LATCH.  
The car seat should have shoulder straps and a pull strap for the harness.  
The car seat should have removable and washable seat covers.

Review: The booster seat overall is very nice. Just  be aware that you  have to assemble it which was a little bit of a challenge for me. It is easy to install and the kids seem comfortable in them.  Also the cup holder is stored UNDER the SEAT for shipping so it took me a while to figure that out. Greco customer service is very helpful with installation questions.

Special Features: Car seat and suitcase sold separately
Review:
This is a fantastic idea, but just isn't easy enough to take on/off quickly and with ease.

I bought this before traveling alone with my toddler, hoping it would provide a solution for easy travel. The reviews seemed really positive and encouraging. My husband and I spent 30 minutes just trying to get our Graco Nautilus carseat securely fastened to our carry-on. Once it was on, I struggled and struggled to take the strap off. We quickly realized this wasn't going to work. I couldn't imagine having to take this on and off in an airport while also holding on to 1-year-old toddler.

In addition, I wouldn't trust the handle on my suitcase to support the weight of a 25 lb. child plus the carseat. It was acting like it was ready to bend or break with just the carseat alone.

I may be more inclined to use this if there is another traveler with me to help, but would definitely not recommend for flying solo with a small child. In the end, we returned it.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Graco Nautilus carseat
Weight Range of Child: 25 lb. child, 1-year-old toddler
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat accommodates a 25 lb. child who is a 1-year-old toddler.

Review:
I did not like that this seat does not have a latch system. Not sure why not? I thought this was a standard. Maybe the price! They do have another seat that kinda looks like this for $20.00 more! It was my mistake for not looking for this feature before buying. My granddaughter fits all the weight / height requirements and I would have gladly paid $20.00 more for a safer seat.
I do like the room for her legs and the seat belt system is so much better than her baby car seat. She can get in it by herself and that is a big help. The only other concern is she is able to reach down and disengage the car seatbelt. Nothing prevents her from doing this. So we explained that she is only to take seatbelt off when we tell her to. I wish I had researched the safety items better.

Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat is acceptable without a latch system and using a seat belt system for installation. The car seat fits all the weight and height requirements for the child.

Review:
I love this carseat! Bought this for my baby boy who is at a healthy weight and doesn't fit in his infant carseat anymore.. The padding in this carseat is beyond enough, that's what I like most about it. Even his old infant seat didn't provide this much padding.
I've read reviews when I was shopping around that the sides were high and can be a hassle to load a baby in and I agree with that. I don't know yet about the forward facing position and loading a baby but definitely a hassle my first few times putting my baby boy in the car. I think after a while mere memory will have you adjust how you load your baby...
The only downside to having this seat and loading my baby is that I have to dig for the straps after loading him.. I did read somewhere when I was shopping that there was another Chicco Nextfit seat that had some way of keeping the straps out so its not so much of and issue after you load your baby..I just didn't think it was necessary to pay extra for that.. but if someone out there is reading this, I say invest the extra bucks because I wish I did.
Apart from that, I love my Chicco Nextfit!!!!

Review:
[[VIDEOID:a128f1aa93a8691307e102076882e525]] They rattle. Model CC138-DWVA Safety First Grow and Go 3-in-1 Convertible rattles where the adjuster handle meet the bar that it lifts to raise and lower the headrest. It's really bad when the seat is empty. I contacted the manufacturer and they sent me 2 new ones (I bought 2 of them originally) and they have the same problem.
I do not recommend modifying your car seats. On the one we are throwing away (they verify you disable the seats when doing warranty replacements) I found that a 3/4 inch of 3/8" fuel line on the adjuster lever behind the seat could make it stop rattling. I don't know why they don't rubberize it. I did it as a test to show them via skype.

Review:
REf: Graco TurboBooster Highback Booster Seat

First off - we LOVE Graco products. We currently own 6 of their car seats and have owned multiple other Graco items - always great quality. This one missed the mark in my opinion in that it doesn't attach to the vehicle. While this may be fine for a normal booster (just the bottom part), in high back mode this thing moved all over the place with a smaller child. (8 yo, 46 pounds). I did not like that when unoccupied it could potentially become a flying hazard in an abrupt stop or accident. Returned and purchased a different model (Atlas 65 2 in 1 Harness Booster). We own 2 other atlas 65s and couldn't be happier. 5 point harness for the 4 yo and seatbelt for the 8 yo... attached to the vehicle and VERY safe - Atlas 65... much better.

Review: my daughter (14 mo) seems very comfy in this seat. it is HUGE, so make sure that your vehicle is large enough. the ONLY disappointment is the fabric, which many are using now. what's w/the shinny stuff? some claim it's more heat tolerant. i'm not so sure about that. on really hot days, my daughter's head still gets pretty wet. plus, it seams to really show water marks. i haven't washed the pad yet, so maybe those come out. all-in-all a great purchase for us. it appears to provide my child with a safe and secure ride. plus, no recalls on this one so far. i would buy it again, but would try a different fabric.

Review:
Bought the ultimate comfort series version from a BM retailer. This is a very good car seat. I was considering the regular Marathon version which was $30 less however the clicktight is so worth the extra dollars. All you have to do is line up your seat belt in the proper slots then shut the seat back down and that's it! Rock solid installation. Seat will not budge. In rear facing recline mode, it didn't take as much space from the driver seat the way my chicco keyfit 30 infant seat did. I'd say I had an inch more clearance for the driver even while reclined.

I have it in a 2014 Odyssey and am able to place in it the middle of the second row. Normally car seats in the middle slide around since the middle area has a smaller contact patch but with the clicktight, it will not budge. I also have had it rear-facing in the rear passenger seat of a 2009 Corolla and it fits and gives the front passenger enough space to be comfortable.

Review:
I gave this 3 stars because it does what it needs to do: it latches into the vehicle securely, it holds the baby in place, and it seems extremely impact resistant. BUT it is so incredibly inconvenient (at best) that I would NEVER buy this car seat again.

It was really easy to install and latch securely (even better than either of the 2 infant car seats we had), the tilting base is nice and easy to use EXCEPT you can't tilt it to readjust once it's latched and tightening the latch system changes the angle of the seat. So we had to install it, check the bubble, loosen the latch, change the tilt, and reinstall it which was pretty inconvenient.

The strap to tighten/loosen the 5pt harness is comically short. I have to loosen it all the way and my 10month old's arms still get stuck in the straps when I try to get her out. Then the strap ends up under the covering and at a weird angle so I have to climb into the backseat and stand up to get the leverage needed to tighten it. It sucks.

My daughter looks obviously uncomfortable in the seat as well. Like her lower back is pushed forward awkwardly and she screams about being in the carseat way more than in the infant seats. But she seemed fine with it in the store that we tested it out at so I'm not sure if it's the angle for the rear facing that is causing the issue or what.

Also my daughter is small for a 10month old (19lbs) and the chest strap and shoulder cushions seem really big on her, I can't imagine putting a newborn in this carseat.

Installation Type: Latch
Harness Type: 5pt harness
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:

Review: I bought one of these for my son 2 years ago and now one for my daughter (7 months old).  The knob for tightening the straps took a little getting used to but after using one rear facing that had a strap, I much prefer the knob on this car seat.  It is great and easy to use and my son enjoys it.  The cup holder is pretty much useless but that's ok with me.  I also LOVE the way the straps can easily be adjusted for height--I feel this allows for the best fit all of the time.  It is a pretty wide seat so if you want to get more than 2 seats across the back of a car or would like to be able to fit someone else in the back seat with them then this is not the seat for you.  (We have a Pontiac Vibe.) Anyway, love this seat and the price is great compared to some other brands.

But,  this car seat is the hardest thing to get out of the car...in and out of the car. The buckles are very hard for my small hands.  I absolutely hate it.  I have a second child which will be ready to move to a convertible and we were going to use this one , and switch the bug kid....but nope.  I can not take it out at all...if I want to wash the cover, I have to get my hubby to help. If I want to get new parts because of a recall, I have to ask...you get the picture.  It is awful.  I had to write a review to let you know about the extreme difficulty of getting it in and out.  I  hoping to get a new seat, and I live Graco products so hopefully they have a better option around the same price point.

Review: Let me first say that this booster carseat is awesome but....and this is my own fault....it is not for children under forty pounds. Review: Our son is 10 months old and not heavy at 20lbs, but he is long at 31 inches.  He is too tall to get into his infant car seat.  Expecting to have to use a car seat rear-facing for another year plus, we have been shopping for a convertible seat.  My husband and I were looking into the Britax and Recaro brand convertible carseats.  When we got the Recaro, it's a nice seat but when installed rear-facing in either a Toyota 4Runner or BMW 3-series wagon, it nearly blocks your ability to see through your back window.  We are told the middle is best and rear-facing is best but how dangerous is it for me to drive with reduced visibility?  I know that the baby weight limits are reduced with the Combi Cocorro, but we should be able to use it for at least 2 years and it meets our safety needs perfectly. Not to mention that the seat is adorable.  It is also easy to get our little man in and out of it, which makes us all happy.  I installed it myself in the 4Runner. My SUV is a 2001 so I don't have the Latch system.  I used a pool noodle under it and also installed the tether strap.  It was not difficult and the seat is very secure.

Review:
When my daughter was close to outgrowing her car seat, we purchased this seat and the Graco Nautilus to see which one was better for us. The Britax Frontier, in my opinion, is a higher quality and more desirable seat.

The biggest thing that stood out immediately when we were adjusting the straps in both seats was that my daughter, who was 2 at the time, already needed the bottom strap with the buckle to be set in the last slot to be a comfortable fit for her in the Graco seat. In the Britax seat, we only needed to put the buckle in the 2nd slot, with plenty of room to grow. I knew I wanted to leave her in the harness as long as possible instead of switching her to the booster as soon as she hits the minimum weight, as many parents do. Since she was already in the last slot at age 2, I am sure that she would've ended up sitting on the strap instead of having it come down just in front of her as it should. I know this wouldn't be comfortable if the straps were tightened appropriately and it really doesn't seem all that safe.

The next advantage of the Britax seat vs the Graco seat was the method to adjust the height of the harness shoulder straps. In the Britax seat, you just push a button on the back of the seat and pull the headrest up. On the Graco seat, you have to completely unthread the harness straps and rethread them in the higher slot. This isn't really hard, admittedly, but it is a pain in the butt and Britax's system is so much easier.

The installation of the Britax seat is not as easy as that of the Graco. The angle of the belt path and the LATCH system buckle is awkward. What I've found works is actually getting into the car, putting a knee in the seat and using my weight to push the seat tightly against my car seat while I tighten the straps. This is the only way I've been able to get a really secure fit. I cannot pull the straps tight enough to keep the seat from wiggling more than the recommended 1" without using my weight to push the seat down first. I drive a full sized SUV so I have plenty room to do this but it might be pretty awkward in a smaller vehicle.

The cupholders on the Frontier are fantastic. It is so nice to have one for a drink and one extra for a snack, or a toy, or whatever. Really, it seems like a small thing but it does make a big difference. I often bring along an extra small cup to hold snacks neatly in the cupholder. A snack in a cup in a cupholder is much, much less messy in a car than a snack held in a small child's lap. The Nautilus had some very cool secret compartments in the arm rests that my daughter really loved but I, personally, prefer the functionality of the cupholders.

The HUGS system that holds the chest straps in place seems pretty gimmicky to me. I don't think that they help all that much. I still have to adjust the chest buckle every time I buckle my daughter in and it is kind of annoying to have to adjust the HUGS thing, too. I also accidentally pinched the skin on my daughter's neck when it got caught between the firm plastic HUGS system and the strap as I adjusted it up. It wasn't a serious injury but it made her cry and it has made me resent HUGS even more. The padding around the straps to protect the neck, on the other hand, are great. They stay in place, are very soft, and my daughter has never complained about being uncomfortable.

You do have to remove the straps completely to remove the covers on both seats so there was really no advantage either way in this category. Since purchasing the seat, I've started using the Summer Infant Deluxe Piddle Pad. It is easy to remove and clean that pad instead of the whole seat and it was fantastic when we were still potty training. Even though we haven't had a potty accident in the car in quite some time, we still use the pad in case of occasional food or drink spills.

We've had the seat now for about 6 months. It still looks brand new. We've actually purchased a second seat just like it for the other car. The Graco Nautilus went back to the store.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: adjusting the straps; method to adjust the height of the harness shoulder straps; push a button on the back of the seat and pull the headrest up; HUGS system that holds the chest straps in place; padding around the straps to protect the neck
Installation Type: LATCH system; angle of the belt path and the LATCH system buckle is awkward; tighten the straps
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The harness straps should be easy to adjust for height. The harness should have a simple method, like a button, to adjust the shoulder strap height. The harness should include a system to keep the chest straps properly positioned. The harness straps should have padding for comfort and to protect the child's neck. Review: I have been using Britax seats for the last two years and have been very happy with them.  When it was time to buy another seat I decided to buy this one so that I could use 5 point harnesses for my 45 and 75 pound kids instead of just going directly to the booster seat.  I read the reviews about the seat being hard to adjust after it was installed and that is true.  However, all that I had to do was to release the click tight and adjust it then push the click tight back down again.  My click tight is pretty easy to get secured, it does not take a lot of force to get it to snap in.  And releasing the click tight is very easy, I just lift up on the back cover of the seat and you can easily see exactly where to place your fingers and squeeze to release it.  Adjusting the bottom strap was not intuitive when I was trying to put the seat in on a cold and dark evening and I ended up having to open up the owners manual to read it first but then it just took me about 1 minute to get it adjusted.  Both of my kids have tried this seat and like it so I am ordering a second seat.

Review: This car seat is fantastic! I bought it to replace a Britax Boulevard after I was in an accident. While I liked the Britax's higher sides, the HUGS pads and straps were hard to adjust and uncomfortable for my little one. The Graco 4ever is much more comfortable for her and it is definitely sturdy. Install was easy and the seat is surprisingly more compact than I expected, which is great. The straps are easy to adjust and I love not having to re-thread the straps! Just lift the headrest and go. I anticipate that we will be able to keep the little one rear-facing up to the limits. I really have no clue how they made this seat so comfy and spacious, but still fit so well in my car! It is a bit heavy so if you are going to be transferring this seat between cars, you might want to go with something lighter.  Also, the chest clip sometimes is tricky to release, I don't know if that is just me or the clip.

Review:
This is our second Britax Marathon Clicktight car seat. I chose it for my oldest based off reviews I read from Babygearlab.com. I had no reason to not choose it again for my youngest.

We love the quality of the seats and ease of installing. They are heavy seats so I wouldn’t recommend this for someone who travels often or switches between cars because that could be tiresome.

It is thoroughly padded which makes for a comfortable ride. I remove all the pieces and machine wash them occasionally because sometimes they need a good washing. I try to air dry them but will sometimes throw them in the dryer on low heat if I need them done quicker.

There are labels on the car seat to reference when installing it and a bubble level. I found that I needed to recline the seat more once I placed it in my vehicle because the captain seats are slanted. Otherwise, the seat would have been too far upright for a rear facing baby, if that makes sense.

We start using these seats on their first birthday because we feel they are safest in their infant car seats until then.

We are pleased with our car seats. This is what I recommend to my friends looking for convertible seats.

Review: When buying a seat for your child, why buy anything other than the safest seat available? This is my second britax advocate clicktight, and I'll never buy anything but Britax. I've had another kind of seat, and just no. It's for emergencies only. I'm very thankful for the addition of the safewash fabric. This was not available when I had my first. I definitely recommend buying the liner, too. Crumbs collect in the bottom, under the clicktight lid, and cleaning under there is a major pain. Also, this is a pretty large seat. I drive a Ford fusion and from having two in the back I can tell that there is no way a third can fit. I can sit inbetween, so there is room for a smaller adult or child, but it's not somewhere I would want to ride for a long period of time. Also, both of my littles are rear facing and that greatly reduces the amount of legroom for the driver and front passenger. Being 5ft 5 inches I can drive comfortably but it's a different story for my 6ft 1in husband. He drives a Jeep Grand Cherokee and we find that he has the legroom issue in it, as well. It doesnt matter to me though, I'd rather get a larger vehicle than compromise on safety. Also, these are made in the USA, which is icing on the cake for me.

Review:
About me:
- I have owned this car seat for more than three years.
- Successfully installed rear and forward facing in:
- the center backseat of a 2008 Mitsubishi Spyder Eclipse Convertible
- all six rear positions of a 2009 Chevy Traverse
- all three positions of a 2011 GMC Terrain
- bucket seats of a 1997 Chevy Minivan
- DD is currently 3ft tall/30 lbs, and she still fits well in this seat!

Things I love:
- Color combos and fabric choices are awesome. Padding is easy to remove and washes well.
- Seat belt button is nice and stiff! Easy for adults, but my three year old has not figured out how to get out of this one.
- Easy to install and very light weight. No base to adjust. Easy to get proper horizontal line.
- Not tall or bulky, so you can see out the back window over the seat. If you're trying to fit three across, this is also a good choice. Nice and narrow.
- Child sits deep in the seat. I feel like this one provides a lot of side impact protection. Also, easier to keep a child rear facing, because their legs are not bunched up against the seat.
- Rated for rear tethering, which very few seats allow. This gives you better protection against rebounding in a crash.
Things that I don't love:
- Newborn padding puts newborns in an awkward position, significant recline compared to Britax Marathon and Combi Shuttle, head is pushed forward more than I would like.
- You have to overlap the two parts of the bottom clip and insert them together. My solution: always loosen the straps before buckling, then tighten back up with the pull strap. You'll get a better fit that way, anyways.

FYI:
- You cannot install this one using an inflatable seat belt. Although I don't see why you'd need to, since vehicles with the new seat belts are also new enough to have latch.
- The weight limit is 40lbs / height limit is 40". If you really think you'll leave your child in a convertible seat until they're in kindergarten or later, then you may want to invest in one that has a higher height limit (like a Radian). If you plan on buying a booster with a five point harness, then don't stress about it.

Review:
We purchased the Graco ComfortSport at Target in Sept of 2010 as an emergency replacement for our previous carseat after an accident. (We actually got the Creighton model.) I have 3 major concerns about the safety of this seat:

1) The shoulder straps do not tighten evenly. After looking at the back of the seat I realized this is due to the design of the set yoke; most seats have two individual hooks for the shoulder belts, tightened by a single pull strap. The ComfortSport overlaps the two shoulder straps under a single hook and one strap will always be a little looser than the other. This also crates the potential for the overlapping strap to slip out of the hook, as it is barely held in place by the hook.

2) The chest plate is easy to unbuckle, even for young children. I looked up advice on how to solve this issue on Graco's website- apparently many parents were having the same issues and Graco's response was that parents should just explain to their children why they need to keep the belt on. After pulling over 10+ times on a two-hour trip because my 2 year old didn't understand my explaining on why this belt was intended to keep him safe, I settled on buying self-adhesive Ace wrap to wrap around the buckle so he couldn't mess with it.

3) The tightening plate on our model broke after only 11 months of use. I was tightening the strap, as usuall, and the single screw the holds the plate in place pulled out and flew somewhere in the car. If this had happened during an accident, the shoulder straps would have been loosened about 2 inches and greatly reduced the protection of the seat.

I had contaceted Graco regauding my concerns about the seat, and asking for a refund. They sent me a letter stating that if I had problems with their product, I should ship it to them at MY expense and they would replace the seat with another one of the same model- no refund. Needless to say I just went out and bought a different, better rated seat for my son.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Harness Type: shoulder straps do not tighten evenly; overlapping strap under a single hook; shoulder straps would have been loosened  
Harness Type: chest plate is easy to unbuckle  
Harness Type: tightening plate broke
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The shoulder straps should tighten evenly.  
The shoulder straps should remain securely fastened.

The tightening plate should be durable and not break.

Review:
Overall this car seat gets the job done. I previously had a Chicco and chose this carseat because it's the lightest carseat around and I loved the the color options. My review is mostly comparing the two.

Pros: It's light.

It's good looking.

Snaps easily in and out of the base.

Cons: It's very long. Whoever sits in front of this car seat has an uncomfortable ride because they will have to pull their seat so far forward.

It's awkward and uncomfortable to carry. There's no padding on the handle and it's hard to carry for longer than a run from the parking lot to the cart.

The canopy doesn't move easily, is floppy, and sometimes gets in the way of locking it into the base. Due to the stiffness in moving it I am now the proud owner of a replacement because the canopy hub cracked and wouldn't hold the canopy up.

The strap to tighten or loosen the harness is also awkward. You push it down, but to get good leverage on it you end up holding down the very strap that you are trying to loosen. On that note, it's also difficult to tighten.

When I called for a replacement part for the canopy I was told that there is no replacement but since it was still under warranty I'd get a replacement. Cool. In order to get a replacement I needed to send in 5" of the safety strap, a 5" square of the pad, and the serial sticker and once they received those they would send me the new seat. Wait, what? You don't have a second car seat? Then they charge you a hefty deposit that they will refund once they receive those items from you. Seems slightly wasteful to destroy a perfectly good car seat that has a cracked canopy hub.

If I had to choose a carseat all over again I'd go back to the Chicco (which is only 1lb heavier) for ease of use, functionality, and ability to fit in our vehicles (out of our Pontiac G6, Chevy Avalanche, and an old Mercedes we all fit comfortably in none if them). Maybe the designers can work a few of these kinks out for the next model.

Review: So, after barely two years of use, the harness straps would no longer stay tightened.  I called Britax and they recommended I clean the area where the straps thread in the crotch area with compressed air and that I tighten and loosen the straps 10-12 times.  I did that and the straps remained tightened again.  However, after a month, the same problem occurred.  I followed the steps Britax recommended and it started tightening again.  Well, after the THIRD time this happened in two months, I called Britax again, sent them a video and then was told that my seat was no longer under warranty and I would have to buy replacement parts that, in my opinion, would not fix the issue.  Considering two years is well below the lifespan of the seat, I decided that after seven years and five Britax car seats, they were no longer the company for my family since their products are unreliable and the company doesn't stand behind them.  Boy, am I glad this happened, because now that I am researching car seats again, I've discovered that Britax is no longer the safest brand.  In independent crash test results, this seat scores a 4/10.  The harnessed booster that I have for my son experienced catastrophic failure in crash test.  This brand is NOT to be trusted.
Attribute_Related_Content: Harness Type: harness straps would no longer stay tightened
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The harness straps need to stay tightened.

Review:
The WORST!!! The states specificstions on the item are false. My daughter is well below the weight, height and "seated height" for the product yet, she no longer fits into it.

I contacted Britax. They were dismissive and finally, after several calls, a supervisor suggested that I call customer service and order an extended harness. I'd have to pay around $25 plus shipping. This isn't a huge amount but is an unacceptable solution for an item that states it should work for my child for at least another year or longer.

I've now purchased a booster seat, far sooner than I wanted. The goal was to keep my daughter in the car seat as long as possible (as recommended by all safety agencies).

Last note, not only is their product horrible, but the customer service is outrageously poor!!!

Review: I've NEVER had so much trouble out of a car seat before in my life... I have installed & uninstalled this thing probably 4 times since we've bought it. My daughter is 8 months old but small & has a muscle disorder. When she falls asleep her head falls over. Even with the extra head  cushion It falls. We drive a traverse and the seats are slanted, so I've had to put towels & blankets underneath to prop it back, still does not help with the falling head issue. The latches... So hard to figure out. The directions didn't help so I had to watch YouTube videos.. Still the seat was very wobbly. I also installed using the seat belt & when tightened if makes the seat lean!!! The only GOOD THING about this is how soft and comfortable it is. I hate that we spent so much money on this seat & it has been a total bust.

Review: If you looking for something compact...this is totally the way to go.  If your looking for lots of bells and whistles,  this isn't for you.  It's compact b/c it cuts out all the extra frills of a carseat...but leaves the important details.  It's super comfy, it lays your baby back enough so if they are a sleeper when they ride - they can do so without their neck breaking.  My baby is 9 months and 19 lbs and she still fits comfy with the insert in...so I'd say she has plenty of room to grow.  NOW...your going to read a lot of people with issues with the seat flipping up in rear facing,  in the anchored / tethered position.  Well this is true, but I took the tether strap that runs from the back (the one you tether in fwd facing position)..and ran it under the carseat,  tethered it to a seat anchor and this thing isn't going anywhere!  It's the most solid seat I've had yet!  You just have to do your homework before installing.

Review: Attractive looking seat. Minimum efforts put into it. The foam is extremely thin, you can press down on the padding and feel through the plastic. The actual seat itself, the plastic- is not hard like our other Graco. It is flexible and I can bend, push, pull it. For reinforcement, there are two thin one inch bars. Our other seats have much larger and stronger reinforcement bars. I picture in my head, a large vehicle hitting my baby girl side of the car and this seat does not feel safe to me. We are returning and purchasing the Britax One4Life. My heart says no to this seat. My bank was happy but I don’t feel like this would protect my girl in my sedan. This would be better for an suv, van, truck. But overall please check the plastic and make sure you’re okay with it before you use it for you child. It is a great seat because it has a circular cup holder, it only has one but some have square cup holders! So that’s nice. We purchased because the seat cover removes easy and our daughter gets sick in the car easy but I will invest in a steam cleaner just for her Britax. It does not have a removable cover at all, only the headrest from what I read so that is a downside. The cost with the accessories is $500. This seat is budget friendly definitely and much safer than many car seats you can find at Walmart or other places. Nice seat just not safe enough for us.

Review:
I love this car seat. I am an avid researcher and also work within a reasonable budget. I have an average sized sedan, but it sadly does not accommodate all car seats. I had the Britax B-Safe, and it was a snug fit for any passengers, and any front seat passenger could only recline the seat so far. Rather than buying a car to fit a seat, I figured there will be more options for the convertible car seats. Wrong. I tried every. single. one. at Babies R Us, to zero avail. I was trying to stick within a less than $200 budget so as much as I drooled over the NextFit it was too pricey ($299.99 at BRU).
When I did the test fit, it was considerably comfortable. It is much narrower in the base compared to other convertible car seats. It has multiple recline positions so if you're fitting it in a small car rear-facing, you can adjust it so your baby is safe but the front passengers can also be comfortable. Also, the overall height of the seat isn't ridiculous. For people not in an SUV- other convertible car seats literally were touching the roof of my car (ie all the Safety 1st brands!) They are so tall, I literally fit in them. This seat has a great adjustable head rest so by the time my child is tall enough to fully extend it she will be forward facing and it will blend into the car's headrest but while smaller and rear facing it has a lower height profile.
I am only 5'3 and 100lbs, so getting straps tight has always been a downfall. With a husband deployed, I was honestly really nervous it would be a nightmare. Using LATCH, with the classic style strap to tighten plus the come-along style pulley, I was able to get it so tight it doesn't budge. I do recommend for those with leather, you put non-slip underneath! The straps can extend pretty long, so you wont have issues reaching your LATCH system (the Britax were just barely long enough even in my small car).
My daughter loves her new seat, she can see much more out the windows and its comfortable as far as I can tell. I have zero issues tightening the shoulder/chest straps as others have mentioned. The actual strap you pull is substantial and easy to get leverage on.
I am sure we will enjoy this seat as my child grows. Chicco, I am a convert.

Review:
I bought this when it was a great price for our spare seat in my husbands truck. Here are some of my observations.
-it's HUGE. Like side to side it takes up a lot of space.
-it's very light, which you would think is nice but when it comes to a car seat it makes me nervous. Like how sturdy can it be if it's so light?
-it is a pain in the butt to install when using the latch system. It just has cheap clips not the nice kind that pricier seats have. And I have the hardest time tightening and loosening the latch strap. I have to make my husband do it after I usually end up cursing at it a little bit.
-it doesn't have protective cushions on the straps so my son usually ends up with red marks on his neck from where they dig into him.

Overall, it's ok for a cheap spare but I wouldn't want this for my every day car seat. We have 2 other brands in addition to this one and this is my least favorite of the 3.

Review: We purchased the Britax Frontier booster car seat 2 years ago for our children who were 5 and 3 at the time.  I picked the Britax Frontier because it covers such a wide range of height and weight.  I thought it would be the car seat that would take them until the end of needing car seats.  I was wrong.  My children are small for their ages (now 7 and 5) with neither of them weighing 40 lbs yet.  They still cannot do the buckles on the 5 point harness themselves.  I find it annoying that I have to unbuckle my 7 year old because the buckle is too difficult for her to undo.  Sometimes I even have difficulty with the buckles.  This is our 3rd version of Britax car seats and this seems to be a very common problem with them.  Plus the fabric is terrible.  We have the red/black seat and it was stained within the first month of use.  Plus when washed it piled and looked even worse.  It is not worth the amount of money you pay for this seat.

Review: We ordered these car seats for our 2nd vehicle.  This is my first experience with Graco seats and overall I'm impressed (our other seats are more expensive brands).  It was very easy to setup and install in the car, and they look really sporty and cool (as cool as a carseat can look) in the back of our family sedan.  The seat is big enough that it will protect the kids, but compact enough that it doesn't overhang the edge of our car seats or block our view in the rearview mirror.  As others have said, the strap that goes between the legs is very short and not adjustable.  My children haven't complained, but it does make buckling the seat a challenge (kids have to lift their rear off the chair so that I can reach the buckle).  And the plastic chest buckle is difficult to take off, but it keeps my kids from letting themselves out.  My kids love having their own cup holders to put their stuffed animals and toys in.  The seat seems pretty well padded and my son fell asleep in it yesterday after 5 minutes so it must be comfortable.  I like how the seat will work for us for the rest of childhood... converting to booster seat options.  Overall I'm impressed with this affordable seat.

Review:
Piece of garbage that is placing my child at risk. Buyer beware. The straps on this seat are able to be pulled completely free of their securing points by my 15 month old. He is strong but no infant should be able to disable their car seat . The top of the straps are able to be pullex free of the toggles on the back side. This allows my son to get himself out of the car seat. I have ensured the seat is properly configured and adjusted. This is not a user error issue but rather graco utilizing sub standard securing methods.

If a infant can pull the straps free using his upper body what's the chance this will fail in an impact. The chance is too high for me to take. I am purchasing a competitors seat and will never use your products again further I am so upset that I will recommend to anyone I know that they not use your seats either.

Child safety is the most important aspect of your business you fail at the only thing that matters .

-Kyle

The top of the straps must stay properly threaded and secured within the toggles on the back. The securing methods for the harness must be reliable and not feel substandard.

Review:
My son normally rides in a [[ASIN:B005MQRAAK Diono Radian RXT Convertible Car Seat, Shadow]] but I wanted something small and lightweight for flying. This seat did the trick. Easy to carry through the airports and easy to install on the plane.

I wouldn't use it as a daily seat unless I truly needed a budget option because the straps twist easily (a common issue I've found on inexpensive seats). It also has a low height and weight limit so it won't last long.

Review:
My 20 month old daughter and I were in a bad crash. Rear ended while stopped, the car hit us at about 40-50 mph which made the car turn sideways and hit the car in front of us (two impacts - rear and driver side). The car seat was installed on the driver side, so the impacts were on the same side as the car seat. Our car is totalled. I was able to walk away but with some very bad bruising and cuts and back injury. My daughter was completely unharmed - not a cut, bruise or bump. She was rear facing (which is important to do, even beyond the legal requirements) which I think helped save her from any back or neck injury. As soon as we got home, I ordered a replacement. I am still amazed at how she was so well protected.

The cover is fairly easy to take off. There are plenty of videos on youtube for demonstration. They are machine washable which is great. It is so easy to adjust the seat and harness height.

One negative: the level attached to the seat is on the opposite side of the tension strap, so when installing you have to be on one side to make sure it's level and the other side to pull the slack in the belt. I also don't like this seat for newborns. Technically it is approved for infant use, but I prefer a "pumpkin" style seat until she was big enough to sit up on her own.

I have bought this car seat 3 times now and would absolutely buy again.

Parents, install car seats correctly. Use the harness correctly (tight, clip over chest bone). Rear face as long as possible (3-4 years). Those can make a huge difference if the unthinkable happens.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear facing
Weight Range of Child: 20 month old, newborns, 3-4 years
Installation Type: tension strap, belt
Harness Type: harness, clip over chest bone
Material: cover, machine washable
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should be suitable for newborns up to 3-4 years old. It should be a rear-facing seat. Installation should be possible using a vehicle's seat belt or a tension strap. The seat should have a harness with a clip that secures over the child's chest bone. The seat cover should be removable and machine washable.

Review:
I initially would have given this 5 stars but after having it for around 2 years I'm not in love with it. My second child will be in need in of a convertible seat soon and I will not be buying a second NextFit. While it does the job and is a solid and good seat, there are enough irritants with it that are causing me to pass a second time.

- It is HEAVY. Changing cars is almost unbearable and my parents refuse to do it because it is too heavy for them. It is very awkward getting it into the back of sedan like vehicles, all around a massive pain to move. If you NEVER or very rarely change it out this might not be a huge factor for you, but it is a bear.

- When rear facing, it can be really hard to tighten the straps because it is SO close to the seat. This might be the case with other car seats too, but my parents especially complain a lot. I can do it, but I don't love it and I have to use a lot of force. Which leads to the next issue.

- My current seat is actually a replacement from Chicco (INCREDIBLE customer service) because the plastic casing around the orange button to loosen the straps kept popping out and eventually the plastic broke because to tighten the straps you have to pull up instead of at the same angle as the strap given how close the strap is to the seat. (kinda hard to explain) Well this same issue has happened on my current seat. I cannot tell you how annoying it is trying to tighten the straps and the whole plastic bit pops off.

- The button to raise and lower the headrest which also adjusts the straps seems a little flimsy. Every now and then when my 3.5 yr old gets into the seat I notice that the headrest has gone back down. It takes a bit of wiggling and jiggling to get it lock again at the correct height.

- It's hot. The seat doesn't breath well. It's really cushiony which is nice, but at the cost of being hot. Fortunately my daughter doesn't overheat too much, but my son always is really hot in his carseats, so this seat definitely won't work for him.

- Even with the strap covers, my daughter gets lines and irritants in her neck. Maybe I'm overzealous in my tightening, but I do feel bad after a long ride and I see her neck.

- All the inclines seem kind of a waste. I can only have the seat included at 1 or 2 rear facing for it to be in the correct level. Any other inclines take the seat out of the level area. Not sure about forward facing as I haven't switched around to that yet.

All the pros that people mention are true, but for the above reasons I won't get another one.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Seat Type: Rear Facing, Forward Facing, Convertible
Weight Range of Child: 3.5 yr old
Harness Type: straps, strap covers
Material: plastic, cushiony, doesn't breath well, hot
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat should accommodate a child up to 3.5 years old. It should be convertible between rear-facing and forward-facing positions. The harness should include straps with covers for comfort. The seat should have a cushiony feel. It is acceptable if the materials do not breathe well and can feel hot.

Review:
We spent a lot of time reviewing convertible carseat options for our 2000 Corolla. It was crucial to us that two adults could sit comfortably in the front seat and one in the back seat with the carseat installed. We also wanted a seat that was easy to install with the seat-belt and that provided good safety features. After a lot of research, we felt that the cocorro delivered on all our criteria. We have been mostly happy with it. The installation is fairly easy and straightforward, although it took a while the first time. The rear facing fit with the seatbelt, on the corolla, is extremely tight. The fabric feels nice and the light green color insures my son won't get as hot in the summer. A few reviews complain about pilling/dirt on the fabric but I haven't noticed those issues, even after a airline travel with this seat. My son seems very comfortable in this seat and he generally falls asleep (unlike in his infant seat where he would just cry).

One problem we have had is that it is fairly easy to crack the headrest foam during installation. When pressing against the sides of the car seat during installation, we heard a crack. I'm not sure if it was the EPS foam cracking or un-gluing from the frame. We continued using it because I read that slight cracks in the foam does not impact performance, but the plastic shell should really extend around the headrest.

Review:
1st off I ordered in January 2015 and got a unit made in Sept 2014. It's updated for proper lap belt seating and it costs less than the "new version".

I don't give 5 stars for anything not manufactured in the USA or made with anything toxic - so a 4 star rating means the product is solid but core manufacturing methods are at issue with my preferences.

This seat is comfortable for my 5 year old boy. He enjoys it, it is reclined and his head does not nod forward when he's asleep, and I'm at ease knowing all risk has been seriously mitigated in the event of an accident. For him and for passengers next to him.

The securing method is honestly great. Once you understand it, you can take it out of one car and place in another in 4 very realistic minutes, maybe less.

I bought this for my new 2015 vehicle and it's going to jack up the seat and the seat belt but I do not care. Seriously. My new vehicle means nothing to me if it's not as safe as possible for my son.

The roads are crowded with more and more people every day. More people choose to text, email, and take selfies while driving because they haven't lost someone dear to them over distracted driving. These people make my blood boil. The selfishness is absolutely mind blowing for me - I could never understand the self absorbed reasoning behind this junk.

So if you think accidents don't happen and little kids/babies don't get violently injured or killed due to dumb ignorant and vain worthless humans, go talk to a first responder about what they witness - then make a choice on how safe you want your child.

Once she woke up we placed the carseat on forward facing position and it was easy to install back and forth. When the car seat is in forward facing position it won't inclide FYI. On the other hand on our KIA Sonata the installation is a bit of a challenge due to the latch not being long enough for easy latching. It IS possible but requires a lot of patients. Review:
We just purchased the boulevard g4 in Laguna, and this is the fourth Britax seat we own. Currently, we have another boulevard, a frontier and a parkway sgl. I love them, and I will never buy anything other than Britax. Since my oldest was born 10 years ago, I have gone through numerous graco, evenflo, safety 1st and Eddie Bauer seats, that were all junk compared to Britax. I thought all car seats were crappy, and I would just have to deal with them. That is, until I bought my first Britax 5 years ago. Since then, I have done my research on car seat safety, and I personally would never trust a cheap seat again.

The boulevard has many great features. My favorite is the separate latch straps. I get a tight fit every time, and no need to untwist straps threaded through the seat. The easy adjustable headrest, removable cover without unthreading the harness, headwings, hugs, safe cell technology, steel reinforcement and tether that can be used rear facing- all wonderful! Not only great in safety, but also convenience.

There is only one con I can come up with, on this pattern. This would never, ever deter me from buying a Britax.
The material: It is so strange to me, how every pattern that Britax offers, varies in material. Some of them are all velvet/microfiber/plush, some are nylon, some are cotton etc. The Laguna blue color is a cotton material, so it doesn't seem as though it will clean up easily. It seems as though it will absorb any dirt or spills. Also, the black trim is a harder, scratchy material. So that is found on the headwings, infant pillow and strap covers. Now, it does not bother me enough to exchange it. I prefer color on the seats, and this is currently the only color offered. But, I own another boulevard, that is made of a plush material, and it just seems logical to offer a softer material on the head. It doesn't bother the baby at all though, so I don't think it's a huge deal. The only part that bothers me, is the shoulder strap covers. Since they are harder, they don't bend as easily and seem as snug as the other ones I have. The other two seats I own (boulevard and frontier) came in different materials and are a much better fit. And my other boulevard, frontier and parkway all are made of a different material in the middle. That material is easier to clean, and seems more repellant.

So, if buying this again, I would still purchase the Laguna pattern. But if they offered Laguna in the same material as sterling or onyx? I would choose that option. I just don't know why Britax can't be consistent with their material. Oh well! Their seats more than make up for their material choice. I just wanted to point out the material on the Laguna, in case someone would want to know. I look to these reviews, when making a purchase that I can't see in person.
Attribute_Related_Content: Material: The Laguna blue color is a cotton material, so it doesn't seem as though it will clean up easily. It seems as though it will absorb any dirt or spills. Also, the black trim is a harder, scratchy material. So that is found on the headwings, infant pillow and strap covers. But, I own another boulevard, that is made of a plush material. The only part that bothers me, is the shoulder strap covers. Since they are harder, they don't bend as easily and seem as snug as the other ones I have. The other two seats I own (boulevard and frontier) came in different materials and are a much better fit. And my other boulevard, frontier and parkway all are made of a different material in the middle. That material is easier to clean, and seems more repellant.
Synthesized_Customer_Needs: The car seat material should be easy to clean and resistant to absorbing dirt or spills. The material should be soft and plush, not hard or scratchy. The shoulder strap covers should be flexible and allow for a snug fit. The overall material should be consistent in quality and easy to maintain.

Review: Let me start off by saying...this is bulky. There is NO WAY you can fit three of these in a back seat...at least in a small suv like mine (kia sportage). However, this is the easiest car seat I have ever bought. I had a baby trend baby car seat...hated it. It's too bulky and too heavy with baby in it. I was never able to lift it and carry it comfortably. This is much better, even though, you can't really take it out of the car with baby, it's still the better option. 1) so easy to put in. The little buckles just snap in place, so cool. It has a leveler in the car seat (For rear facing) that will let you know immediately, if you're doing it right...it's foolproof. 2) the rest of the buckles and straps you'll need for forward facing are attached to the seat...so you will NEVER lose them, when the time comes to actually use them, that's cool. 3) the seat belt actually is able to be moved up and down by also moving the head rest up or down...so there is no need to take the car seat apart and thread the belts back through a taller opening to accomodate growing baby (like the graco nautilus)...you just move the headrest up and the belts move up with it...genius! Overall, very easy to use, but like I said, no way to fit three in back seat. Also, it's like a cocoon, so ,my baby has a hard time being able to see his older brother, who is facing forward.

Review: We just bought 2 of these for my Subaru Forester. We had 2 Chicco Nextfits, but they were bulky and hard to tighten. So, we wanted to try something else and looked for something slimmer. This was an obvious choice, and it had good reviews and a nice price. The Slimfits came in, and compared to the Nextfits, they are almost exactly the same size. I did not gain any actual backseat room, though they do have a slimmer appearance since there's not so much padding. And that's the other reason they're getting 3 stars - they're much less cushy & comfortable. The cushioning is slim, too. The Slims feel less solid, less safe. They were also a little harder to install tightly since there's only 1 tightening strap, and the Nextfit has two. However, the harness straps seem to tighten more easily, and that's a big deal - I was struggling with the Nextfit every day. So, this may not be a bad carseat, but it doesn't look good next to a Nextfit.

Review: My daughter was in the infant seat for too long. She is on the smaller side and I just realized at 16 mo and 19 lbs she needed this seat. I did TONS of research on seat prices and safety and found this to be the most highly rated and the best made. STEEL framed instead of plastic - most all are PLASTIC framed surprisingly - WHAT?! YEAH - AVOID GRACO! And the adjuster for the shoulder straps is great. The day before they fit and the next morning they are too big because they grow so fast - amazing - but just grab the headrest clip thing and voila in one second you are on your way with your baby fitting properly without pulling the whole darn thing out and that whole fiasco. The most persuasion for me to buy this seat was the MANY MANY reviews I read about these seats being in pretty big accidents and the baby never budged an inch. That is the bottom line. Good job Britax. Something that is actually NOT CRAP! And she can use it to 70 pounds which is well worth the cost. Will buy one for our second car.

Review:
I bought this car seat almost two years after researching car seat safety for a long, long time. My granddaughter isn’t with me everyday but spends enough time with me that I need a car seat in my own car every day. When she was infant I used a Chico infant seat for her . It was fantastic and I really thought I’d purchase another Chico when she was ready for a bigger seat.
All my research led me to Britax and the Advocate. I wanted the safest seat I could get for her. I am not very handy, so I needed something easy too. The ClickTight sounded pretty perfect. So I decided to go with the Britax Advocate ClickTight, after reading every review I could find.
Let me say it is a heavy seat and I don’t like to move it around. That’s why I never move it unless there’s a great reason to do so. I was a little intimidated when I first tried to install in my car. When I felt frustrated I just went back to manual and even googled some things I couldn’t quite picture. Installation and adjustment was amazingly simple!
Every time I need to adjust, I refresh my memory with a quick google video or the Manuel and it’s so easy...once again, let me tell you I am not good at this type of thing. My only problem getting baby in seat has been when she’s being playful and won’t sit still so I can buckle her.
It does take two hands to fasten and unfasten the belts on her seat but that just keeps her safer, in my opinion- meaning she can’t get out by herself.
I’ve washed the cover and replaced it on seat. I did get really confused at one point and thought, “this is crazy! This can’t be right!” When I read instructions on replacing cover. Well, after I reread a couple of times I realized I was trying to put the cover on the wrong place. Yep, it was me doing it wrong! After two years I just can’t say anything bad about this seat. Thankfully, we haven’t been in any accidents so I can’t speak to that. I love this seat, even two years later. It looks great, works great and keeps my love safe.
Attribute_Related_Content:
Installation Type: ClickTight
Harness Type: belts
Material: cover
Synthesized_Customer_Needs:
The car seat is easy to install using the ClickTight system.
The harness uses vehicle seat belts for securing the child.
The seat has a removable and washable cover.

Review: I'm the grandmother, and my granddaughter grew out of her infant car seat (the one you can carry around).  Yes, it's expensive, but the features and solid construction make it worth it.  Best Feature:  You can adjust the height of the straps while the baby is right in the seat, just takes a minute (shoulder straps must be above the baby's shoulders, not dipping behind their back, and this seat makes it SOOO easy to keep that safety feature in place).  And, it's good through 65 lbs. Granddaughter #2 is on the way in April, and I will buy another Britax for her when she's about 6 months old.  What helped the most in my purchase decision was a glowing review on the seat by a Mom, so I hope this helps another person trying to decide.  PS: I suggest you sit with a cup of coffee or tea and read through the instruction booklet, then go get acquainted with the seat and features.  In a short time, how to install and all the features will be very clear.  My granddaughter is SO comfortable in it, I can tell, her head doesn't bob forward and she always falls asleep in this one.
